I keep my umbrella folded, even when it drizzles, just to feel the fine spray on my face. Some people call that stubbornness. I call it calibration.

Most mornings I take the long route to the university, because the short route passes my old school and I am easily ambushed by the ghosts of teachers with dry voices. I prefer the university’s smell: damp stone, coffee burned at the edges, notebooks unfurling like white flags. I am twenty-one, supposedly proficient in noticing the right details and ignoring the ones that land like needles beneath the skin. Supposedly.

We live in a flat with a balcony that almost faces nothing: a sliver of street, a distant chimney, a bird that always looks like it has somewhere else to be. It became ours the way most things do—someone else moved out of it, and we moved in. My father has a habit of arriving in rooms half a step before his shadow, and the night he came home with her, he stood in the doorway too long, as if he had miscounted his own footsteps.

“This is my daughter,” he said, turning to include me, though I had already been there, coiled like a spring on the sofa. “And this is—this is Alba.”

He didn't say “Alba is your—” because the word step-sister sat in his mouth like a coin he had forgotten how to spend. The legal papers had not yet been notarized, but the logic of the situation was simple. He married her mother, and two families became a single inventory. Chairs, plates, winter coats, griefs, habits. You think you can list them. You cannot.

She was taller than me by a head and a question mark. Her hair was black, not the soft brown of my father’s beard or the lighter ash that my mother’s photographs show me, and when she raised her eyes I felt something change in the room's size. You should know I am not easily impressed by eyes. But these eyes—they were like two storms that had decided to become lakes. You could drink from them. You could drown, if that’s what you wanted. I thought I knew what I wanted. Then I met her.

"Hi," she said, and her voice was warmer than the radiator in December. She wore a white shirt tucked into jeans and a wristwatch that ticked audibly. "Your dad said you liked Thelonious Monk? My stepfather—our stepfather, sorry—he said that."

“He did?” I looked at my father, who looked at the floor. I had played one Monk record twice, three years ago, when I was trying to get through a breakup and a bottle. I failed at both. If you ask me to name a favorite musician, I say “it changes” in a voice that makes it sound like I am being generous.

"Yeah," she said. "I brought some records. We can play them, if you want."

“We don't have a record player,” I said, and then felt stupid. But she smiled. "We have one in the car," she said. "I wasn’t sure, so I brought it. I tend to bring my own weather."

She brought more than weather into our flat: she brought light into corners that had resigned themselves to darkness. She unpacked smooth plates and a cactus with bruised arms and a lemon-yellow kettle that whistled like a mile-long train, a kettle that would scald us into wakefulness every morning. She brought a poster of a city that wasn’t Oviedo (Lisbon, yellow tram caught mid-sigh), a scarf with constellations printed across it, a jar of buttons. She brought her mother, who looked at my father with eyes full of forgiveness and math. Together we lined the shelves. Together we pressed ourselves into the smallness of a kitchen that was suddenly a stage where four people practiced the choreography of a new family.

Night fell like a hand over the windows. We ate tortilla and smooth slices of tomato and something from a jar that Alba had made, peppers swimming in oil and garlic and vinegar. What is it called? Escabeche. I pulled a chair close to the table and listened to them talk about the easy details of merging: who takes out the trash which day, who buys the salt, who remembers to lock the balcony door, how eggs always go missing in families. From time to time I caught Alba’s eye across the table, and her smile was small and true, like a ribbon tied where nobody else would see.

"And what do you study?" she asked me, halfway through a second glass of wine.

"Linguistics," I said. "Words about words."

"Ah! So you carry a mirror to the world, and there's a mirror inside, and another mirror inside that. Or I am mixing it up with barber shops."

"I can do barber shops, too," I said, and everyone laughed. And later, when the laughter had become the hum of dishes and the itch of sleep, I stood at the sink and Alba dried the plates, and we talked about the things that reveal nothing until you discover what they were hiding. We didn't talk about mothers or fathers or who had come from which direction, because those were obvious, or at least publicly obvious. We talked about the bus routes she had studied of her new city, the secret timetable of rain, the way the pigeons on the cathedral know the schedule of the human soul.

"What about you? What were you doing?" I asked, making a shape with my palms in soapy water. "Before here?"

"I was in León," she said. "Studying architecture. But I needed a change of air. Nothing dramatic. I didn't have to be saved. I just wanted to look at new roofs."

It sounded almost like a joke. It was not. There are jokes that open the door to a secret, and there are sentences like this, which are keys.

That night I lay in my bed and listened to the new sounds of a house that had grown by one heart, then another. Alba's room was the one across the hall from mine, the one with the window that faced the sliver of street and the chimney; she had placed the cactus on the sill, as if she were warning pigeons that this was a thorned place. I heard her move around and then settle. I counted the beats between my pulse and hers, as if the walls had become a stethoscope. Past midnight, I got up to drink water. The low lamp in the living room cast a lemon half-glow over the record player she had set on the cabinet. Beside it, a paper bag. I pulled it open and saw a stack of records, different shades of cardboard and memory. Thelonious Monk really was there, “Solo Monk,” next to Nina Simone and a band I had never heard of, and something that had no label, just a hand-drawn crescent moon.

I didn't play anything. I replaced the bag, went to bed, and slept five minutes at a time, like a cat waking on the hour to observe the world’s ongoing disaster. Maybe this is this. Maybe this is one of those crossroads I have been told to avoid. Maybe it is one of those crossroads you step into and then become road yourself. I was not naïve. I knew the words for almost everything. But names fail when the truth becomes a person in the next room, asleep.

My mother’s picture on the dresser watched me with its old-gold sadness. She had left when I was eleven, for a city whose name my father still avoids. Not dead, but not here, which is its own kind of ghosting. When I met Alba, I thought, casually, you remember those faces you see once and then never again but they stay? That. That was my first thought. It was not good or bad. It was just the truth.

The city rose and sank. Alba learned to walk Oviedo the way a dancer learns to walk normal when she must. I learned the new weight of silence when her door was closed. We found rituals. We made breakfast together on Thursdays and argued over the crispness of bacon we could barely afford. We went shopping for things that seemed to multiply when you tried to count them—sponges, carrots, pens—and we carried them home in string bags that cut into our palms in a way that felt like proof. Proof of what? That we had hands, that they did more than satisfy our phones, that we could still build something more substantial than lists.

My best friend Mara from the university said, "So, what's she like," in the half-mocking way only a best friend can manage. We were eating empanadas on the steps of a building that was pretending to be a castle. I gave her the surface answers: tall, funny, architecture, León. I did not tell her the deeper fact: that when Alba stood in a doorway I wanted to catalogue the shadows she erased.

"You going to play her the Monk record?" Mara asked.

"Already did," I lied. "She was unimpressed."

Mara squinted at me. She has a face built for skepticism, a mouth that curves naturally into "Really?" "Careful, T," she said. "Families are like... you know when you fill a glass to the brim and it holds just slightly more water than it should, because of surface tension? And then you move it one millimeter and it spills. That."

"I'm not moving," I said. I was lying to her and to myself, in the same breath, the way bees talk to one another about flowers they haven't found yet.

We spent a Saturday afternoon at the Museum of Fine Arts because it was free and dry and large enough for people to disappear inside. Alba studied buildings in paintings the way a surgeon might look at a hand. She tilted her head as if dissections could be done at that angle. I drifted from room to room, reading placards and thinking about the paint that thickens and thins across a canvas, the way you can see time as a substance. When we met in front of a painting of a street in a rainstorm, she said, quietly, "They always make the rain look clean. It isn't. It always has a little of the city in it."

"You're new here," I said. "You can't be nostalgic yet."

"Maybe I am not nostalgic," she said. "Maybe I am just precise."

We ate sandwiches in the courtyard. I don't remember what was in them. I remember the way her sleeve brushed my wrist and electricity traveled up my arm like a rumor that wouldn't die. I remember thinking: say nothing. That is the rule. Keep the words inside. They are yours. You don't have to donate them to the catastrophe fund.

My father stumbled into a happiness he wore like a jacket two sizes too big. He whistled in the mornings, a thing he had not done since I was small, and he looked at his phone at dinner the way teenagers do: not to escape but to take pictures of pasta, to show the world, “Look, proof, evidence, an ordinary holiness.” Alba’s mother laughed when he sent them, teasing him, and he let her. You could see him learning to be seen, which is harder for men of his generation than anyone admits.

One night, after we had gone to the weekly jazz jam in a bar that pretended it was in New Orleans and still managed to be convincingly here, we walked home through the kind of drizzle Oviedo deploys when it wants to remind you that an umbrella is not a structure so much as a symbol. Alba tucked her hair behind her ears and looked up at a balcony where a cat sat like a judgment carved in stone.

"I've never liked cats," she said. "They look at you like you're a plot twist they saw coming."

"I like that," I said. "It means you can't surprise them, so if you manage to, wow."

"And you?" she said. "Do you like to be surprised?"

"I like to be prepared for surprises," I said. We both laughed because it was such a Tallulah thing to say, and because it was impossible. A week later, she would be sick. A week later, I would learn exactly how little preparation is worth.

But this is not the story of a sickness, not exactly. Or, if it is, it is the story of a city that lowers its eyes when people cough in winter and of a hospital that hums regardless of who is watching.

She came out of the bathroom on a Tuesday morning looking pale but amused. "The water is making a strange sound," she said.

"That's because the building is a decade older than God," I said, buttering toast with an aggression that was not about the toast. "It needs to sigh before it functions."

"No, it's—" she started, and then she put a hand to her forehead. "I think I'm—"

"Sit," I said, not knowing what else to do except wield the imperative. I pressed two fingers to her wrist as if I had become a nurse without training. The pulse was there, fast like a rabbit in a hedge. Her skin was hot.

"Maybe it's nothing," she said. "Maybe I'm dramatic. You know I have that capacity."

"Me too," I said, but we did the sensible thing and took her temperature. The number blinked at us, then settled into a range that makes mothers worry even if they are two cities away. We made tea. We called the hotline the university sent around with flu season warnings. It was the season. The voice on the line was calm.

"Rest, fluids," the voice said. "If she has other symptoms—"

"What other symptoms," I said, as if I could outrun them by listing them.

"Shortness of breath. Chest pain. Confusion."

"She already has confusion," I said, and Alba laughed, reflexively. The laughter ended in a cough that sounded like a nail in a board, sharp, bright, inevitable.

"Call us back if it gets worse," the voice said, and then we were alone with the tea and the pink tiles and the responsibility adults carry even when they pretend they do not. She carried herself to bed and I brought her water and the lemon-yellow kettle sang its long train song and the morning took on the hush of a church where somebody is praying too hard.

Her mother called and called again. My father, at work, came home early and then left again because work has that way of believing in its own necessity. Alba slept. I sat by her and read from my linguistics textbook, words about words that did not make words behave. She woke and smiled and said, "You're using your voice like a blanket," and I said, "Go back to sleep." Outside, a siren went by that sounded like a child trying not to cry.

When the fever climbed a second step we called a taxi. The driver had a face like a saint’s statue left in the rain too long but his hands were steady. "Hospitals," he said, in the tone people use when they mean, "Another one." He made the city small, and the hospital grew large at the edge of it, white and humming, a ship in harbor. We went in with our paper masks and our quiet fear. They took her, they talked to her, they measured her, I waited. I was useless and entirely necessary in the way loved ones are: I answered the questions she couldn't be bothered to answer, I offered nothing useful but my presence. It is not nothing. Even when it feels like it is.

"There is a bed," the nurse said, with that shy triumph they wear when they can give you the one thing you want that they can actually give. "It will be a day or two, maybe more. Fever. Hydration. You know."

"I know," I said, and I did and I did not. I wanted to argue with the air because it had failed to stay invisible in the right ways.

They moved her to a room in a wing with white corridors and blue signs that called themselves by numbers. 3C. Room 12. The walls were the wrong shade of forgiveness. The window faced a parking lot that believed in its own optimism because of one tree that had not yet given up its leaves. She was installed like a patient in a textbook illustration: bed, monitor, table with rolling wheels. The nurse stuck a name on the door like a badge on a uniform.

"I'll stay," I said, but there were rules, and they were rules because people are not good at not being near one another when one of them is burning. Visiting hours. Masking. Hand gel. Watch the trickle of numbers on the screen as if they were the score of a game you could influence by sheer attention. I did not like the rules. I obeyed them.

She settled under thin blankets and made a joke that made the nurse laugh and the nurse said, "We like you. You're not the crying kind." I was the crying kind. I cried in the bathroom stall where the soap smelled like oranges. I cried in the cafeteria when they announced that the arroz a la cubana was finished. I called Mara and said nothing until she said, "You sound like air in a bottle. Do you have what you need?"

"She is okay," I said. "They say she's okay. Fever. Rest. The usual."

"The usual is the most terrifying thing," Mara said. "Do you need me to come?"

"No," I said, because it had to be no. Not for any noble reason. Because my panic had narrowed into a thin passage that would not allow other bodies.

When I returned to the ward, she was asleep, and a young woman sat in the chair by her bed with a script balanced on her knees. Her hair was shaved on one side, dyed blue on the other, and her fingers shaped words in the air as if she were casting spells. She saw me and stood up quickly.

"I’m sorry," she said. "I didn't want to— I was waiting for the nurse. They said your—your sister? She was dozing. I'm Carmen. They put me here yesterday. I talk. A lot."

"It's okay," I said, surprised by the sudden relief of another human who was not a nurse or a vending machine. "I'm Tallulah."

"Beautiful name," she said, as if offering me back myself. "I— I'm in theater. Well. I study theater. Sometimes I pretend hospital rooms are stages. It helps. With the fear."

"Does it?" I asked.

"Yes and no," she said. "Everything helps. Nothing helps. Sorry. I say contradictory things when I haven't eaten. Do you want peanuts? I have fifteen packages."

We laughed softly the way people do in libraries and church. Alba shifted and opened her eyes. When she saw an extra person in the room, she smiled, a ghost of her usual brightness, but a brightness nonetheless.

"This is Carmen," I said. "Our neighbor. Of geography, not life."

"Hi," Alba said, and Carmen’s fingers shaped a hello in midair. Later I would learn she had a deaf brother and a habit of signing even when nobody else could understand. Later I would learn she had the kind of energy that makes hospitals less like ships and more like docks where you could lean and talk to someone about what the sea had taken. Later, too, I would learn to hate her with a ferocity reserved for saints. Not because she did anything wrong. Because she existed where I wanted to be the only one.

You see the fix, right? The equation that shows its teeth but not its solution?

The nurse came in and told me I had to leave, because the clock had rolled into a square called Visiting Ends. I wanted to argue with numbers. I did not. Alba squeezed my hand. Her fingers were warm, no longer too hot. "Go," she said. "Sleep. Bring me a list of streets that have trees. The city has many. I want to remember them from here."

"Okay," I said. "I'll bring you a list." She smiled like a lit match.

Outside, night had become a glaze of rain over cars that could not be bothered to shine. I walked home with the lemon-yellow kettle singing in my head. The flat was more empty than it should have been, even with my father and Alba’s mother making tea, their voices careful and bent. I told them what they wanted to hear: that she was better, that the nurse liked her, that the window had a view of a tree. They clung to those facts as if they were handholds on a cliff. Later, when their room was silent and the city yawned and rearranged itself, I wrote a list of tree streets. Calle del Rosal. Avenida de Galicia. The little square by the pastry shop where the plane trees pretend to be flocks of sheep. I fell asleep with the list under my hand.

Days do what they do best: they pass. Alba slept; she woke; she made friends with a volunteer who played guitar on Tuesdays and a nurse with a tattoo of a key behind her ear and a boy with a broken arm who wanted to know every story an adult carries but never offers to boys in casts. She sent me messages that were sometimes misspelled and sometimes sublime.

They have a banana pudding machine here, she wrote. It is like a miracle glued to a plug.

You would like nurse Ana, she wrote. She says words like "spectacular" about small things, and then she does not retract.

Carmen says hello. She brought me a play with a character who only speaks in questions. Do you imagine what that would be like? Are you exhausted yet, just thinking about it?

I imagined it. I was exhausted. I was also incandescent with the kind of jealousy that has no place beside a blood pressure cuff. The hospital had become a city of its own, with its own weather and customs, and she had begun to live in it with a grace that made me proud and furious. What is the opposite of loneliness? It is not company. It is being needed. I was less needed. That is good, you will tell me. That is exactly the thing you want when someone you love is ill: you want the illness to release its teeth. I know. I know. But the human heart has a perverse engine. Ask anybody.

I went to my classes. I turned in an essay that argued that the word "stone" has different weights depending on who carries it. It was not my best work. I talked to Mara in the cafeteria and she looked at my face the way doctors look at X-rays.

"You should say something," she said.

"Say what? 'Hi, I have fallen in love with my step-sister, and also she has the flu, which is a terrible plot for a student film.'"

"Say that," she said. "To me, for starters, you idiot."

I looked at my hands. I had always liked my hands: competent, almost pretty, capable of balancing coffee mugs and sentences. They looked untrustworthy now, like tools left in the rain. "It will pass," I said.

"Which part?"

"The feeling. The flu. Both. Neither. Shut up."

"Okay," she said, and then she did me the kindness of changing the subject to a professor we both hated because he smiled when he said sadism-adjacent things. I loved her for that.

In the evening, I took Alba the list. She used her finger to trace the names as if feeling their bark through paper. Carmen sat on the windowsill in a position that would have broken an ordinary spine and read aloud from her play. The boy with the cast wandered in and listened and then wandered out when an orderly told him to. Nurse Ana leaned in, said "Spectacular," and left. The room had become a crossroads where stories paused, exchanged glances, went on. I hovered like a lamp. I offered water. I touched Alba’s forehead with the back of my hand and made a joke about my medical degree. She laughed and then coughed and then laughed again.

"You're getting better," I said, but I meant, You are moving away from me into a space I do not own.

"Am I?" she said. "I feel like a page in a book somebody else is writing. Oh—Carmen, read the part where the question-woman asks the mirror if this is her face or just practice."

Carmen read it with too much feeling and it was perfect.

Later, I walked home alone again. It is a short walk, but there are nights when it expands like a lung. The rain that night was careful. It kept to its lanes. My father had left me a note in the kitchen—Went to get soup. How is she?—and then three question marks that tried to look like flowers. I made tea. I sat at the table with my linguistics book open and did not see any words at all. I thought of Alba's smile at Carmen's reading. I thought of Carmen's hands drawing words in the air. I thought about how the human heart is a badly designed room: no exits, too many doors.

It would be too simple to say: that was when I started to break. It is never just one moment. It is a sequence of almosts. The glass of water you almost dropped. The call you almost answered. The word you almost said. The night I did break, I woke before dawn to a dream of the balcony and the cactus unfolding small white flowers that smelled like milk. I went to the window and watched the street shine under the new day’s first thin brush. The city was briefly innocent. I felt the thing in me that had been holding together, despite itself, begin to unknit. Not a dramatic rending. A careful undoing, the way my grandmother used to take out the stitches of a sweater that had gone wrong because nobody had wanted to admit it.

That morning the hospital put up a sign about visitor limits and flu season. It had always been there in spirit; now it was there in blue letters. "We need to reduce contact." Carmen sent me a message: They’re saying fewer visitors, shorter times. Don’t hate me. I’m already here because of the ward next door. I can peek. Guilt is my superpower.

I stared at my phone. Then I turned it off. Then on again. I went at the appointed time and they were strict at the desk. The nurse with the key tattoo put her hand on my arm. "We'll make sure she's okay," she said. "You can call at night; I can hold up the phone. She likes your lists. Bring another list. Of sounds."

"Of sounds," I echoed, because I am a very obedient person when given the right kinds of impossible tasks.

I sat with Alba and made a list of sounds while the minutes shrank into their own copies. The kettle. The bus braking on the hill. The pigeons pretending to be applause. The neighbor who sings as if he lives under the ocean, everything bubbled. She added her own: the hospital’s bottle of gel clicking, the paper curtain moving as if it were breathing, Carmen’s laughter. We made a list that took us to the end of visiting hours. When the nurse said time, I had nothing to argue with. Not numbers, not God. I kissed the crown of her head, quick, light, not the way I wanted. She closed her eyes in a way that was an answer without language. Then she turned her face towards the window, towards the tree that insisted on its own leaves.

I walked out under the sign that reminded me to clean my hands. I walked down the corridor that smelled like weak coffee and perseverance. I walked into a city that had decided it was November even if the calendar had not fully agreed. I walked home to a flat that had too much air in it and closed the door too gently. I looked at the record player and the bag at its side and pulled out the unmarked record with the crescent moon and set it on the platter and lowered the needle, the soft drop, the quiet crackle. Music began. It sounded like a dawn that could be delayed with the right word, if only I knew it.

I did not know it.

It was in that stretch of days, close enough to the beginning to still be considered an introduction, that the future grew a hinge. I did not notice it. Hinges are like that: visible, unremarked, the reason doors open and close. If you want to know when doors are significant, you look at the metal that moves them. You listen for the hinge. But I was listening to a record, and rain, and the kettle singing its train song. I was watching a cactus for flowers.

In the hospital, Alba learned the names of night nurses—Lucía, José, a man called Nano who hummed under his breath—and Carmen started a game where she collected the small lies hospital signs tell, like “ha ocurrido” instead of “está ocurriendo” and “silencio” that nobody obeyed. She made Alba laugh until she coughed and then brought her water and apologized and did it again. The boy with the cast drew a picture of a ship that was really a bed with wheels and gave it to Alba and she taped it to the wall with medical tape because she had decided to live there, for now, and a wall without children's art is a wall that thinks too well of itself.

I tried to carry on. But the city had shifted, its iron taste stronger in the rain, its pigeons more like confessions with wings. On the fourth night, I woke to the sound of a siren that did not fade. I sat up and waited for it to halve, then quarter, then silence. It did not. In the morning, the hospital called and said nothing alarming, and I exhaled in outrage at my own body for having held breath for hours. We adapt; we shatter; we adapt. There is a sequence there, and we move through it like dancers who pretend they invented the steps.

When Alba was finally feverless for a day and then two, the rules did not bend but they stopped pressing on my sternum. I could stay a fraction longer. I could bring in oranges and peel them for her at the little table and the room smelled like something living. I could watch her sleep without doing the unkind math of what I might lose. It deserves to be remembered: those days existed. The ones before I let the hinge become a crack become a way into a different story. The ones before I moved toward that door and opened it with my bare hands.

Chapter 2 began on a morning that looked like a clean plate, and if you have ever cleaned a plate in a hurry you know it only pretends to be spotless; there is always a smudge if you tilt it the right way. The city had rinsed itself overnight and stood there dripping, proud of its drainage. Buses breathed like animals that had just discovered lungs. The woman with the pigeons was already in position, her scarf knotted as if it had opinions about knots. I left the flat with a bag of oranges and a book I had no intention of reading, and I told myself this was an errand, humility itself, not a decision that would rearrange the furniture in my head. I was practicing lying to myself in the minor key.

At the hospital the blue sign about visitor limits had acquired a new strip of tape that made it look medically important, and the woman at the desk wore an expression that said she was tired of being the favorite aunt of bad news. I was a little early and a little ridiculous with my oranges and my book and my certainty that rules belonged to other people. Nano was at the end of the corridor, a roll of tape looped on his wrist and a pen tucked behind his ear like a cigarette from a different decade. He hummed something that could have been a lullaby or a football chant if you sped it up. When he saw me, he leaned against the wall as if it were an old friend and considered me the way a locksmith considers a key that looks wrong and might still open the door.

"You are early," he said, and there was a smile tucked inside the remark like a folded ticket.

"Only by the clock," I said, because I have never been able to resist an opportunity to be annoying. I lifted the bag. "I brought oranges. They are innocent. They improve rooms."

"They stain sheets," he said, which was both true and beside the point. He gestured at the door. "Two minutes. If a dragon sticks its head out of the ceiling tiles, you didn’t see me."

"Never," I said, and he let me pass, which felt like walking into a small conspiracy that smelled faintly of antiseptic and forgiveness.

Alba was asleep, her mouth slightly open in a way she would have edited out of any photograph. She had that hospital pallor that looks like it was painted on to match the walls, but the heat had left her forehead and taken its bright hammer with it. The tree outside insisted on being the kind of green that ignores weather. I put the bag on the table and sat and watched her breathe, and I thought about how breathing is a thing you do wrong as soon as you notice you are doing it. The book stayed closed. I do not know if oranges can improve rooms, but their smell can make even caution blink.

"Hey," she said after a minute that was more like ten, because hospital minutes are long trains that stop at every station. Her voice was made of dust motes and relief. "Are we breaking laws?"

"Only petty ones," I said. "No dragons have objected."

"Good," she said, and she closed her eyes again and then opened them like someone stepping back into a doorway to ask one more question. "What did the city do?"

"It practiced," I said. "It stretched its rain like a cat. The pigeons were early. The buses remembered their lines. Your mother sent a message made entirely of hearts and one tomato."

"Of course she did," she said, and that made both of us laugh softly in a way that did not wake the machines. I peeled an orange, careful to keep the peel in one piece, because sometimes useless skills are proof that you have a right to exist. I offered her a segment and she took it as if accepting a treaty. We ate in silence. The nurse with the key tattoo came in and said good morning in a voice that could have been poured over pancakes, checked numbers, declared them satisfying, and left the smell of coffee behind her like an afterthought.

"Are we allowed to eat?" I asked, when the nurse was gone, because I needed to be corrected by a rule to feel real.

"No," Alba said. "But oranges don't count. They are spherical permissions."

"That is not how it works," I said, and she smiled at me the way people smile when they agree and will not admit it. She looked at the window, at the tree that had become our third guest, and then at the bag by my feet. "What is the book?"

"A grammar," I said. "Spanish morphosyntax. The kind of thing that makes time slow enough to be measured with a protractor."

"Read me a sentence," she said, and I obeyed, because I am very obedient when obeying gives me an excuse to be near her. I read about clitics and the particle se and the way language makes choices you didn't vote for. She closed her eyes and listened to me ruin everything beautiful about language and we were both comforted,, which is one of the strangest tricks of love, when it goes right.

Carmen appeared in the doorway with a coffee cup and a stack of paper that might have been a script or a petition to abolish hospitals. She wore a sweater with holes that were either fashionable or sincere; with Carmen you could rarely tell. She saw me and stopped and raised the coffee in a gesture that was both salute and apology.

"They let you in early," she said. "You must have bribed someone with oranges."

"Nano is susceptible," I said. "He senses citrus and loses his ethics."

"Good to know," she said, and she stepped in, and the room did change in size, even if I would deny it. She put her coffee on the windowsill and touched the tape on the boy-with-cast's ship picture as if to test whether it was still attached, which I resented for no reason that I could explain. "How are we?"

"We are practicing breathing," Alba said. "Tallulah just taught me that oranges are spherical permissions."

"Of course they are," Carmen said, delighting in a world where nonsense could be elevated to doctrine. "I brought—aha—" She shuffled through her pages and frowned. "Well. I brought a monologue in which the character tries to remember a city only by listening to it. Perfect for your list of sounds."

"Perfect," Alba said. "Read it."

I sat there like a chair that had decided to have opinions. Carmen read, and she is very good at reading; her voice knows where sentences want to be held and where they want to be dropped. I watched Alba's face relax into that place it goes when somebody else carries her for a minute, and I wanted to be gracious enough to be only relieved. I was not. Jealousy is a hungry animal with soft paws; it sits on your lap and purrs and then, when you reach to pet it, it reminds you what claws can do. I said something kind, because I am good at kindness when anyone is listening, and then I left because the minute had turned back into a clock and Nano's dragon had probably returned, impatient.

There is a way to walk angry in a hospital and not frighten anybody, and I learned it that morning. You keep your face polite and your anger in your elbows. You stand at the hand gel dispensers and practice washing your hands like a saint being painted. You let the smell of orange and alcohol compete in your nose. You go outside and the rain taps you on the forehead and suggests you get over yourself. I walked to the university with the bag now light with the absence of oranges and with my book feeling like ballast, and I told myself the sentence I had been avoiding: You are not the only person with a voice she likes. I tried it in different accents. It did not improve.

Mara was in the cafeteria, stabbing a croissant with a fork like a tiny gladiator. She watched me approach and did a theatrical squint that Carmen would have appreciated. "How's the miracle ward?" she said. "How is our architecture saint?"

"Feverless," I said. "They might release her tomorrow. Or the next day. She laughs at Carmen's jokes until she coughs."

"Oh," Mara said, and she did not smile, because she understands me to an uncomfortable precision. "And you laugh at Carmen's jokes until you want to punch something."

"I am not violent," I said, and then, because she is my friend and she has earned certain words, I added, "I dislike how good she is at being human near Alba."

"Mm," Mara said, doing something devastating with three letters. She tore the croissant in half and handed me the bigger piece with the solemnity of a communion. "You're going to have to be brave in one of two directions."

"Define," I said, even though definitions are what I do for sport.

"Tell Alba something true," she said, "or tell yourself something true and then live like it. You can't keep pretending you are furniture. You'll get dusted."

"She is my step-sister," I said, and the word did its old coin trick in my mouth, refusing to be spent.

"Not yet," she said, because she is cruel and accurate. "And even if she is, the heart does not get a family tree. It gets a map with certain roads closed and then it goes off-road anyway, breaking its shocks."

"I hate your metaphors," I said, and she patted my hand in a way that made me forgive her immediately. We ate, and we spoke of a professor who does not believe in commas except when he uses too many, and I went to a class where I learned nothing except that every language has a way to apologize too much, and then I texted my father to tell him I would bring home bread.

At home the kettle drew its whistle as if it were trying to command a train to stop under our window. Alba's mother had left a bouquet of parsley on the counter like a joke about flowers. My father was in the living room, scrolling through pictures of soup bowls, because his phone had learned to interpret his love in bowls. He showed me one with chickpeas that looked like small planets. "I think we should make this when they call," he said, and I nodded and cut slices of bread as if they were decisions I had simply to divide into equal parts.

When a phone buzzes on a counter in a kitchen and your hands are full, you make a choice about whether to wipe them or answer anyway and grease the glass. My phone buzzed and I wiped my hands and picked it up, and there was a message from a number I had not saved because I believe in certain kinds of restraint. Tallulah, it said. How are you. It was a city’s name followed by a question, and it came from somewhere I had decided to colonize as absence. My mother does not write well, which is to say she writes like someone who has learned all her words by memorizing labels. I stared at it the way a person stares at a mirror when the light goes wrong.

I put the phone face down and did not tell my father, because I am the kind of daughter who likes to protect him from nothing. Then I picked it up again and wrote, Fine. Oviedo rains. The iron is still in it. She wrote back, I will visit. The words arranged themselves like furniture I had not ordered. I stood there with the bread knife in my hand and imagined the rooms shifting: a chair that had belonged to one life placed inside another, a kettle wanting to whistle loud enough to drown anything that might follow.

You should know that I did not answer, and that not answering is a kind of answer. I made chickpeas with my father and he took a picture of the pot and sent it to Alba’s mother, who was still at work, and she responded with enthusiastic punctuation. We ate and washed up and he went to bed with the economy of motion of a man who has learned that if he stops too suddenly he will shatter, and I stood in the hallway between our rooms and Alba's and listened to a silence that had lost one heartbeat. Then I opened her door.

I told myself that I wanted to open the window, that the air must be stale, that I would water the cactus if it looked thirsty, because I am very good at inventing good reasons to do things I have already decided to do for bad reasons. The room smelled like her shampoo and the paper covers of books and the ghost of hospital disinfectant she had brought home on her skin the last time she showered here. The cactus held its nerve and its thorns and seemed unsuitable for pigeons and saints. I went to the window and touched the glass and saw my face and the chimney that believes in itself. Then I turned and looked at the things that had been arranged as if the person who had arranged them had left for an intermission.

Her desk had a stack of sketchbooks, and the top one lay open, as if to make the choice easier. There are violins and knives and other instruments designed for very specific motions; there are also hands, which can be used to bless or to steal. Mine did both that night. I held the breath inside my chest as if I could trade it later, and I put my fingers on the edge of the book and turned the page.

There were roofs, as promised: slates curved like shoulders under rain, a cathedral’s spire not even pretending to be subtle, balconies like tongues, gutters like secrets. There were annotations, not in architecture's stiff letters but in a script that danced in its own shoes. "This building wants to lean," she had written next to a sketch of a street whose name I knew by the way it tastes when you say it. "The corner cannot decide whether to be generous." On another page she had drawn the lemon-yellow kettle and made it look like a locomotive, added tiny windows, given it passengers. Beneath it: "We live inside our need to boil. Trains of tea. Warnings of steam."

I told myself that I was allowed to see these things because they were beautiful and because beauty seeks eyes. Then I turned to another page and saw Carmen, tilted in a chair with one leg on the windowsill and the other challenging gravity to a duel, her shaved hair and blue hair both documented with a fondness I felt in my throat. Beneath it, a note: "Carmen reads a room as if it were a play. I do not know if that is healing or manipulation. Perhaps both. She makes even hospital light feel like a choice." I put my hand on the paper and felt nothing but paper, but I had expected my skin to find heat. I turned another page and saw me.

It was not a likeness I would have recognized if my name had not been written in the corner, and even then I might have lied to myself. She had drawn me from the side, from the kitchen, pouring coffee with my elbow held out like a wing, and she had made my mouth softer than it is and my forehead more stubborn. The note beneath it said, "T pours coffee as if she were offering it to a river. Her fingers are always on the verge of music. Count her mercies. Count her bluntness. Count her lists." I did not cry. I went to the window and opened it a fraction, which was what I had promised myself, and the city exhaled into the room as if glad to be let in.

I closed the book because any more would have burned me. I sat on the bed with my hands palm-up as if waiting for coins. My bare hands had done it, and a door that should have stayed closed had become a path. You will tell me it is not as bad as blood or theft or betrayal, and you will be right and wrong. It was a small wrong, the kind you can carry in the pocket of a life until it wears a hole and drops through. I stood and straightened the pillowcases as if that were penance, and then I did the thing that would be less forgivable: I drew my name on the back page of the sketchbook, very small, very far down, a signature of a person who does not get to sign. I do not know what I was thinking. I think I was thinking, If it ever matters, she will see I was here. If it never matters, paper will keep its secrets.

The next day they called to say she could come home. We went in with coats and scarves and the lemons of the kettle in our eyes, and the nurse with the key tattoo pronounced us ready for the world. "The world is less sterile," she said, grinning, "but more interesting." Ana hugged Alba in the manner of someone who pretends not to be a hugger and then takes your air and your bones into her own momentarily. Nano wheeled the bed down the corridor for the theater of it and then stopped, and we put Alba's bag on her lap, and we rode the elevator where someone had scratched a heart into the metal and the cleaning crew could not erase it. Carmen appeared at the doors with a scarf around her neck that looked like a spilled galaxy and said, "Be free, citizen," and bowed in a way that she can get away with. Alba put her hand on Carmen's hand in return, and my jealousy did its familiar, absurd motion in my chest, like a cat stretching.

When we got home, the cactus looked surprised, and the kettle made its speech, and my father practiced being casual and failing. We made chickpeas and the soup of an ordinary day and Alba's mother arrived with bread that looked too handsome to eat and immediately tore it, which is what love does to handsome things. We ate and talked about nothing except what was everything—sleep, appetite, the tree outside the hospital window that would now have to inspire someone else—and after dinner my father put a record on because he is not a man to be obvious but he could not resist the possibility that music would make the world say yes. He chose the Thelonious Monk because he is that kind of romantic: he remembers one detail and repeats it until it is either embarrassing or tender. The needle fell, the crackle spoke like rain on paper, and the piano did what pianos do when they have forgiven the people in the room.

We did not dance. I have seen films and I know what should have happened, but we did not dance because the living room is small and because there were four of us and because joy is sometimes a thing you hold still to hear. Alba leaned back on the sofa with the blanket on her knees and closed her eyes the way you close your eyes when you are learning to trust your eyelids again. Alba's mother held my father's hand for a minute and then let go, and he smiled at something that did not require words. I sat on the floor and leaned my shoulder against the sofa, and Alba's hand slid from the blanket to my shoulder and rested there, warm, a weight that adjusted what gravity meant. She left it there through one song and then another, and I wrote five possible meanings for it in the air and chose none, because choice is a luxury that requires courage I did not have.

Later, the parents went to bed in the embarrassed way of new lovers with children in the next rooms, and the flat shrank to a corridor and two doors and the soft machine of the refrigerator forgiving us our electricity. I stood on the balcony and watched the chimney do nothing with conviction. The street made its small promises to the cats. I heard Alba's door open and close and her feet on the tile, and then she was beside me, the blanket around her shoulders, her hair pulled into a sort of event.

"It smells like rust," she said, inhaling as if to prove the city's consistency.

"It prides itself on that," I said. "Oviedo and its iron perfume."

"I missed our kettle," she said, because it is possible to miss objects the way you miss gestures. "In the hospital, even the hot water tastes like waiting rooms."

"They should bottle that," I said. "Eau de Patience."

"Smells like oranges and gel," she said, and then she laughed and coughed and laughed again. I put my hand out of the blanket's reach and caught the air like a clumsy net. "Thank you," she said, and the words went to a place in me that has been waiting for them since I learned to hear.

"For what?" I asked, and the question sat there pretending to be casual while it bought property in my heartbeat.

"For the lists," she said. "For the way you read grammar as if it were poetry. For the oranges. For not letting me apologize for being afraid."

"You don't have to apologize," I said, and I meant it and it made nothing easier. She leaned her shoulder against mine and we stood like that, two pieces of scaffolding pretending to be a monument.

"Want to hear something ridiculous?" she said, after a while, and ridiculous is a word that can hide pain's shadow when it wants to. "In the hospital, I started designing a building with corridors like this, narrow enough that people cannot pass without touching on purpose. It's bad architecture. It's beautiful."

"It would get terrible reviews from the fire department," I said, and she smiled.

"My professor would send me back to basic drawing," she said. "But I think buildings should force us to risk awkwardness if we want to get anywhere. Otherwise we avoid one another indefinitely and then die."

"We could call it the Department of Necessary Closeness," I said. "Admission by list. Or oranges."

"Or both," she said, and she looked at me with those eyes like lakes that once were storms, and I felt the hinge of the future creak, loud enough to make even the pigeons startle. It is one thing to open a door and read someone's handwriting; it is another to find them opening the same door from the other side, not to catch you, but to join you in the threshold.

We did not kiss. I am sorry if you required that. It would be simpler if I had that to confess. We stood there on a balcony facing nearly nothing and invented a building that would punish our cowardice and reward our better qualities, and then she yawned and I told her to sleep and she made a face because she hates imperatives unless she issues them. She went to her room and I stood there until the kettle felt neglected and then I made myself tea and took it to bed and read three sentences of a book and understood none.

In the morning she slept late because her body was still the owner of itself in a way nobody negotiates with. I went to class and the professor attached himself to a speech about definite articles as if it were a life raft. Mara and I walked out into a drizzle that had chosen to be more felt than seen. "You are lighter," she said, because she is rude and honest and because my face is a betrayal.

"She is home," I said. "She touches my shoulder when Monk is playing. My mother texted me and I ignored her."

"So," Mara said, filing it in the part of her brain that shelves disasters and recipes. "All your ships have arrived at once. Try not to let them collide."

"Do you want to meet Carmen?" I asked, because I am a masochist in small, controlled ways.

"I think I already know Carmen," she said. "We have a dozen of her at the theater. They eat light bulbs and then smile. But yes. Fine. Introduce me to the enemy."

"She is not the enemy," I said, automatic, reflexive, reflexively dishonest.

"Who is, then?" she asked, and I almost said "my mother" and did not, because some words feel like intercoms: too loud, too public, even just between two people on the steps of a building that pretends to be a castle.

That afternoon we went to the old bookstore on Calle San Francisco because the rain decided to aim itself sideways and there are places in the city that understand how to be shelter without commentary. The bookstore still leaned into its own shadow, and the man behind the counter had the same face he has had since my childhood: a map of disapproval with a country of secret tenderness where nobody vacations. Alba moved through the aisles like a person testing a new pair of lungs; she touched spines as if to see whether each book had been taught to behave. I picked up a book of photographs of Lisbon, because she had brought the poster, and she laughed and said, "No, not nostalgia. Research." We bought nothing because poverty loves us, but we held nearly everything and then put it back gently, as if we had borrowed an organ for a minute and had decided not to keep it.

When we came out, the rain had changed its mind, because weather is allowed to do that. We walked toward the university, toward this version of ourselves that made sense in daylight, and we saw Carmen on the steps of the theater building, sitting with her legs folded up like a piece of furniture someone had assembled without instructions. She waved with two hands because that is who she is. "Citizens!" she called, because that is what she calls everyone when she wants to pretend we are in a play that has cast us badly. "I was just thinking—oh. Hi."

"This is Mara," I said, because I had decided to be brave in the direction of reality. "She thinks you eat light bulbs."

"I do," Carmen said. "They are crunchy and full of ideas. Nice to meet you, Tallulah's sensibly skeptical friend. Does she tell you everything? No, of course she doesn't. Nobody tells everything. That would be impolite in a narrative."

Mara raised an eyebrow that has frightened two men and a professor into reconsidering themselves. "I prefer my narratives without narrators," she said, and Carmen clapped as if someone had performed acrobatics in a slow-motion movie. We stood there and performed kindness for one another and I tried to ignore how my skin had learned the topography of jealousy.

We walked home in a cluster that pretended to be casual and stopped to buy eggs that would go missing because eggs always go missing in families. In the flat, Alba went to her room to draw, Carmen sprawled on our sofa like a citizen of the Republic of Sprawl, Mara sat at the table and I made tea because I am always making tea when I am not breaking into rooms. Carmen quoted lines from the monologue about listening to cities and forgot where a period should go and did not care. Mara told a story about a boy who had finally learned to say his own name without apologizing for it. Alba came back with a page where she had drawn the three of us as buildings: Carmen with windows too big for any proper façade, Mara with a door that looked deceptively plain and locks drawn in filigree, me with a staircase on the outside that invited people to climb and hid the fact that it did not go to the top.

"That's cruel," I said, but I was smiling, because I recognized the truth even when the ink tried to disguise it as art. We hung the page on the kitchen wall with a magnet shaped like a lemon and pretended it was a joke, and after Carmen went home and Mara performed a goodbye that included a double eye-roll and a secret smile for me alone, Alba and I sat in the clean quiet that follows people who leave and you still like.

"You went into my room," she said, and it would have been less terrifying if she had accused me of arson.

"I—" I began, because beginnings are harder than endings, and then I stopped pretending. "Yes. I opened the window," I said, which was true and not sufficient, "and I saw the kettle train." I could feel my pulse in my throat like a small angry bird. "I read the line about my fingers. And Carmen."

She did not look angry. She looked like the tree outside the hospital window, uncomplicatedly itself under weather. She took a breath and let it out and did not use the breath to injure me. "Okay," she said, and the word was a small bed I had not expected to be offered. "You could have asked."

"I didn't know how," I said, my voice trying to be a person and nearly succeeding. "I am not good at that door. I pretend to be. I open doors and then apologize to them."

"I noticed the signature," she said, and her mouth quirked like a page deciding whether to curl. "Very clandestine. Very villain-in-training."

"I am sorry," I said. "I am an idiot."

"You are," she agreed, which is one of the kindest things anybody can do. "But you are not boring. And you opened the window. The cactus will write you a thank-you letter."

"Do you want me to not look again?" I asked, which was me learning just now how to be a person who asks instead of takes.

"I want you to look when I invite you," she said. "Which is now. Sit. I'll show you the bad building. You'll laugh. The stairs do nothing. Like hope. Like rules."

We sat on the floor with the sketchbook between us and our knees almost touching and drew lines on paper that tried to be straight and failed honestly, and I understood, for a moment, the architecture of restraint: you draw a room and then you draw a window that refuses to be door-shaped, and you admit that some openings are only for looking. We did that for an hour that lasted the right amount of time, and when the kettle whistled its train, we let it, and when the rain tapped, we let it, and when my phone buzzed with a number that would always be a city, I turned it face down again and told the part of me that is eleven years old and has excellent memory to wait a little longer.

On the weekend we took the list of tree streets and walked them like a pilgrimage for a childish religion, which is to say sincerely, with snacks. We named their leaves as if that could make them love us, and we paused under the plane trees in the square where the pigeons graduates go, and we watched a couple argue, first with hands and then with faces, and then with kisses issued like traffic fines. Alba tilted her head back and watched the canopy as if it were a ceiling fresco, and I watched her watching things I had seen too often to see again, and I thought, calmly and with no hope of remedy, that my map had changed and no amount of erasing would make the old roads reappear.

There were no dragons in the ceiling, though Nano would have obliged if asked. There were only days, doing their trick: passing and building, passing and building, uncertain which building they were making.

Chapter 4 began like a rehearsal no one had agreed to attend, the kind where you show up in your normal clothes and someone presses a feathered hat into your hands and says, Don’t worry, you’ll know your lines when the lights go up. The city pretended at an early spring and failed charmingly; the air had the same iron shavings as always, but the light was a fraction wider, and the pigeons performed optimism with their chests out. In our flat the kettle staged its usual coup at eight, and the radio told us there would be traffic by the football stadium, and my father cleared his throat twice before he said, without looking at me, “We have the registry today. Twelve-thirty. You’re coming?”

I said yes because what else does a person say when the state intends to stamp your family into a single object. On the balcony a shirt had been left overnight and collected the weather like gossip; I unpinned it and folded it and thought about paper that remembers where it has been creased. Alba came out of her room in a dress that could have been blue or black depending on the weather’s opinion, and she put on shoes that made a sound like a polite argument on the tile. She was pale still, the hospital having taken a layer of bravado from her cheeks, but her eyes were the same, those careful lakes that pretend they have never flooded. She looked at me and tilted her head and said, “We should bring something. Lemons for luck?”

“We have three,” I said, opening the fruit bowl and counting the small planets of our domestic galaxy. “The registry will love that. They have a box for citrus, next to the box where they put your sighs.”

“Perfect,” she said, and she slipped the lemons into her bag as if smuggling into a movie theater, which perhaps we were. Alba’s mother came out in a scarf that asserted a position on green, and my father put on a jacket that used to belong to his hope. The four of us walked to the registry office because it is close enough to make walking feel like a moral position. The woman with the pigeons nodded at us as if we were a procession that had finally learned its steps. The buses coughed their white flags and moved on.

The registry office had decided to be cheerful by means of ferns that were barely alive and chairs that stacked into good intentions. The walls were the beige of paper you don’t choose. There was a bouquet on the counter that had been given up by its first recipient and adopted by the State. The clerk had a face that made you want to remember your own name. “Next,” she said, as if this were a continuation and not a beginning, and my father produced documents that contained all his careful mistakes. He and Alba’s mother signed with an ink that pretended to be permanent. The clerk stamped with the gravity of rain. When she pushed the paper back through the slot, something in the room exhaled.

“Congratulations,” she said, without looking up, and there it was, the word that refuses to examine its own assumptions. We smiled and performed the ritual kissing of cheeks and avoided knocking over a fern. A little boy in a sweater shaped like a dinosaur roared so convincingly that the old man beside him smiled despite himself. Alba put one of the lemons on the windowsill and then, when the clerk frowned, removed it and put it back in her bag, whispering to it, “Sorry, bureaucracy.”

On the street again, parcels of sunlight laid themselves on people’s shoulders as if to mark them for delivery to a better place, and the cathedral pretended it had never been a hiding place for prayers that went unheard. My phone vibrated against my ribs like a trapped bee, and I let it because I am the kind of person who believes a beep can be negotiated with. Alba’s mother broke away to call her sister, the one who collects recipes like trophies, and my father looked at the paper as if it might speak in my mother’s voice and say anything that would make the past a different country. Alba and I walked half a step behind them, the lemons heavy with their unspent miracles, and she said, in the tone of someone remarking on architecture, “So. Steps. Stepping. Step.”

“I don’t love the word,” I said. “It makes it sound like we’re always one off.”

“We are,” she said, and for a second neither of us pretended otherwise.

We celebrated the way poor saints do: with coffee and a pastry we cut into careful quarters at a café that never changes the brand of sugar packets. My father took a photograph of our cups as if to post proof that warmth had happened. Alba’s mother asked me if I would come to dinner at her sister’s on Sunday and I said yes before my throat could stage a rebellion. The radio in the café was playing a song that had been trapped in the walls since the nineties and had finally gnawed its way out. Alba leaned across the table and brushed a crumb off my sleeve and I thought about how small mercies are never small to bodies that need any.

After coffee I walked her to the School of Architecture because she had a pin-up, a small critique for a small project with a professor who enjoys being the kind of kind that hurts a little. “Don’t stay,” she said. “You’ll get bored, and then you’ll write a paper in your head about how critique is just a dialect of cruelty, and then you’ll be mad at yourself for being right.”

“I’m a connoisseur of being right at the wrong time,” I said, and stayed anyway, because sometimes boredom is a kind of worship. The studio was a white room that had given up on warmth and settled for the religion of light. Students pinned their pages to the cork wall with the solemnity of people who aren’t sure whether they’re offering their work up for sacrifice or marriage. Alba’s page had the building we’d half-joked into existence: the narrow corridors that refused to let strangers pass as strangers, the stairs that went elsewhere on purpose, the rooms that asked questions on their thresholds. She had drawn small people in pencil, and one of them looked suspiciously like me, hands held out as if to measure a doorway’s intentions.

The professor, a woman with hair like a storm cloud that had earned its electricity, stood back and squinted at the plan. “It’s irresponsible,” she said, and my ribs prepared to defend someone who did not need me as a shield. “And brave. It has the arrogance of youth and the humility of a person who actually looks at how people touch. Your corridors will terrify fire inspectors and make families confess things. I’m not sure which scares me more. How would you ventilate the middle?”

“Skylights,” Alba said, not blinking. “Courtyards that are excuses for trees. If you force nearness, you must remove heat.”

“Good,” the professor said. “And your stairs that go nowhere?”

“Practice,” Alba said. “For all the ways we go nowhere on purpose before we go somewhere we can bear. Let them exist. People will sit on them. They will talk to people they would have avoided.”

The professor smiled the way clouds sometimes part just enough to prove the sun still knows the choreography. “You are intolerable,” she said, and pinned a small yellow sticky note on the page that said, in a quick hand, Keep this wrongness. Use it well. The other students pretended not to be taking notes on courage. I stood in the back, learning nothing about syntax and everything about desire pretending to be theory, and when Alba’s eyes found mine, I did not hide how proud I was in case I would need that visibility later as currency.

Outside the studio, Alba let out a breath she had been saving since morning. “I thought she would set it on fire,” she said.

“She did,” I said. “Now it’s yours and brighter.”

“Come with me to the theater,” she said, and the shift made sense in her mouth; she had moved from rooms where walls speak to rooms where voices pretend to be walls. “Carmen has a rehearsal. They’re using hospital curtains as a set. She wants to show me how not to be solemn about illness.”

We went because afternoons are for infidelity to whatever you said you would do at noon. The theater building smelled like old wood and new sweat. Carmen met us in the lobby wearing a sweater the color of a bruise you can’t explain easily, and she spun once in the middle of the floor because bodies like hers cannot stay still when they have been given an audience. “Citizens,” she said, and then, because she had noticed the paper under Alba’s arm, “Ah, the House of Necessary Closeness. Bring it to my monologues. We will let the chairs be cruel, so the words can be kind.”

They rehearsed on a stage framed by curtains that did look like the hospital’s, pale green that believes it is calming and is often a lie. The director had the voice of a person who has misplaced sleep and refuses to file a missing persons report. Carmen read a scene where her character asks a nurse whether her heart is a prop or the real thing, and the nurse says, You are the only one who can tell by the way you fall, and it wasn’t good theater yet, but it was honest rehearsal. Alba watched with her hand over her mouth, an instinct I recognized from the hospital when she had hidden laughter from a fever. I stood in the dark with my arms crossed like a parenthesis that did not know what it contained.

On the bus home my phone buzzed again with my mother’s city pressed into the digits. This time she did not ask a question; she announced herself as if she were luggage: I have tickets. Friday. I will be in Oviedo at four. Please. I read it twice to make sure the word please belonged to her and not to my invention. I did not answer. I could feel the answer inside my mouth, a coin that had lost its country. When we climbed the stairs, the building’s handrail cool and indifferent under my palm, I told my father because lying would have required a speech I had not rehearsed. He put his hand on the counter, flat, as if feeling for tremors, and said the words he uses when the freezer argues with him: “Okay. We will deal with that when it arrives.”

“Do you want me to tell her not to come?” I asked, and hated how the word want made his face briefly blank, a screen waiting for the wrong film.

“I want you to be less alone,” he said, softly, and I had to leave the room to stop him having to see my face turn into evidence.

The day of the arrival built itself like scaffolding that shrieks when you put too much weight on one side. I went to classes and learned how Spanish absorbs blame into passive constructions with a disingenuous shrug. Alba sent me a picture of a courtyard she had found behind a café, a rectangle of mild light with a potted orange tree pretending to be necessary, and I sent her back a picture of the staircase in the humanities building where someone had taped an apology to the wall for no obvious reason: Perdonen el polvo de las obras, a phrase that always makes me think of the dust we cannot see. At lunch, Mara tucked her legs under her on the bench and listened to me read my mother’s message with the flat affect of a person tasting a medicine before deciding whether to take it.

“Do you have a plan?” she asked, tearing her sandwich into democratic pieces.

“The opposite,” I said. “I have impulses. Fleeing. Hiding. Standing in a doorway and drafting a treaty.”

“She doesn’t get a treaty,” Mara said, not unkindly. “She gets a map. With warning signs. You make them big and legible. You can draw, can’t you?”

“I can list,” I said. “Maps of lists. Lists that map. Items like landmarks: the bookstore that leaned when you left, the kettle that refused to stop, the fact of me being eleven and learning that absence can sit at a table and eat bread with you and not choke.”

“Good,” she said. “Tell her you’ll meet her somewhere that is not your kitchen. Make the first conversation belong to the street. Keep it moving. Don’t ask questions you’re not ready to absorb.”

“Absorb is a cruel verb,” I said.

“It is also a function,” she said, and kissed my forehead like an older sister I never had, which made me want to both cry and salt the earth of the cafeteria.

I texted my mother an hour before the train would get in and told her to meet me by the statue of the man who pretends the city is his. I used words that weighed less than my heart wanted them to. The train arrived. The station breathed its tired metal breath. The plaza around the statue had decided to be a stage for umbrellas. I stood there and put my hands in my pockets and took them out and put them back in and thought about the difference between mercy and method. When she appeared, she was both the same and wrong. The haircut that had been her only indulgence had grown out; the coat that had signaled her belief in big cities had resigned itself to our smaller one; the face that used to move like weather had learned to hold a shape and keep it.

“T,” she said, and I had prepared for the wrong voice. It was lower, or maybe my memory had been too high-pitched. She did not reach for me, and I was grateful. We stood in a greeting that could have been mistaken for waiting for the light to change. “You look like your father,” she said. “And like yourself.”

“You look like Madrid,” I said, because insult and compliment have always flirted in our mouths. We began to walk because walking gives you the alibi of traffic. She told me about a temp job that expected her to be grateful for time; I told her about linguistics as if it were the study of excuses; she nodded as if I had offered her soup. We paused under the awning of a bar where chalk letters promised a calamari that would forgive your life; she smiled at the sign and said, “Asturias,” like a tourist who had had her throat cleared by nostalgia.

We did not mention leaving. We did not mention eleven. We did not mention the city she had avoided in her mouth. I told her about my father’s registry office and she said, “I’m glad,” and I believed her a fraction. She asked after my work in the tone of someone asking the weather about its plans for Friday, and then, as we approached the cathedral, she said, “Can I—can I see where you live?”

“No,” I said, not loudly, not cruelly. “Not yet.” It took both of us a second to reassemble our faces. She nodded. The square noticed the rain decide to fall like a sentence that had been held back too long. “Another time,” she said. “A coffee then? Inside? You look cold.”

I wasn’t, but I wanted to be somewhere that had walls that did not know my father’s name. We went into a café that likes to be dim even at noon. The waitress had forearms that could carry three tables and the kind of joke that nurses tell at three a.m. We sat at a small table near the window and watched umbrellas fail at being boats. We had coffee. We spoke of how the trains lately had begun to act like moody relatives. She asked, too carefully, “Do you need anything?” and I almost laughed, because the list unfurled across my brain like a dropped ribbon that knows how to tie itself. I said no. She asked about music as if I still held onto the version of me that tried to learn Monk by osmosis; I said there was a record player now and resisted the urge to talk about crescents drawn on labels. She said, “I can stay a few days,” and I said, “Okay,” as if okay were a country with immigration control.

When we parted, she touched my sleeve, not to hold me, but as if to check whether I was in focus. “I’ll text you,” she said, and I did not tell her not to. I walked home with the city pretending to be a map and my legs pretending to be sure of the route. The flat was full of the smell of onions turning polite in oil. My father was chopping parsley with the concentration of a man who would do anything to replace one image in his mind with another. Alba’s mother kissed my forehead and called me valiente like a word she would argue with if she had the time, and Alba turned from the stove with the wooden spoon like a wand and said, “Well?” with her eyebrows.

I told the story without adjectives and they nodded in the way people do when they have agreed not to make new weather. After dinner, when the parents went to bed in their soft, embarrassed way, Alba and I sat at the kitchen table with the sketchbook between us like a treaty that made art of its clauses. She drew a corridor that got wider and then narrowed again, an apology and a dare. “Your mother,” she said, not a question.

“She arrived,” I said. “She knows how to wear the word please now. We weren’t unkind. We weren’t anything brave, either.”

“You were a person,” she said. “That’s hard enough.” She shaded a stair so it looked like the beginning of a secret. “Will she come here?”

“No,” I said. “Not yet.”

“Do you want her to?” she asked, and I thought about the kettle, about my father’s jacket, about the lemon magnet holding up the drawing of the three buildings we pretended to be. I thought about Carmen’s stage and the hospital curtains and the boy’s ship, and I said, “I want a world where the answer to that is simple.”

“We can build corridors that force kindness,” she said, “but the doors still decide who they let in.” She closed the sketchbook and put her palm on it as if stopping a small animal from running into traffic. “Let’s be stupid and go to that jam on Wednesday. You can pretend to love Monk again, and I will admit that I like him more than I thought.”

The jam on Wednesday was like every jam on Wednesday except when it wasn’t. The bar’s wood had absorbed decades of spilled courage; the lampshades were still the color of nicotine and forgiveness. A trumpet player in a jacket that had seen too many winters found a note that made one of the bottles on the shelf hum in sympathy. Alba sipped her ginger ale like a counsel who didn’t want to weaken her case. Carmen breezed in half an hour late with a scarf that had decided it was a comet, and she pulled a chair with the confidence of a person who can make furniture forgive her. “I could have used your corridors today,” she said to Alba. “Somebody cried in the dressing room and then we all pretended not to notice for eight minutes and then we noticed for eight minutes too long.”

“How was the nurse line?” I asked, because I had liked it at rehearsal against my will.

“I delivered it as if I believed in it and nobody laughed at the wrong place,” she said. “Progress. Mara is here.” She waved at the door, where Mara stood with an expression that said, of course, there will be jazz now. They collided in hellos that managed to be sincere and slightly competitive, and I sat there and let the music arrange my breathing into new shapes.

To prove that I can surprise myself, I stood when the pianist looked around the room like a man in search of a dare, and I went to the small stage with the microphone that had never liked me. My hands were cold with the knowledge of where they have been and where they wanted to be, and my mouth wanted to bargain, but I said the poem I had not meant to say, the one about iron rain and bus brakes and pigeons that know the hours of the human soul, and it did not sound like Monk because I am not a piano, but it was honest in the way that leaves are honest when they fall. Alba’s face did not move into that expression people wear when they are proud and want credit for it; she looked at me as if this had always been an option I had forgotten to exercise. Carmen put a hand to her heart in exaggerated gratitude. Mara raised her glass and did not make it a joke.

When we got home, the stairwell smelled like somebody had cooked something with too much garlic and no apologies, which felt like a blessing. In the kitchen, the light over the stove flickered in the way that suggests it is practicing dying, and I stood on the counter to unscrew the bulb and because I wanted to prove my usefulness to gravity. “Don’t fall,” Alba said, in the tone of a general who has learned to issue orders in the form of kindness. I didn’t. We drank a tea too late for sleep and stood by the window and watched the night perform itself correctly. My phone vibrated again and I let it because my hands were busy with a mug and because I had promised myself not to be the person who always answers the person who always left.

My mother wrote, The city is beautiful at night. She wrote, I walked past your school. She wrote, I am sorry in the way that does not ask to be believed, only to be heard. I put the phone down and did not look at Alba, and she spared me by looking at the kettle as if it were a god we didn’t believe in but sacrificed to anyway.

Thursday turned itself into a performance of being fine. I went to class and argued with a boy who said that words do not mean until someone wills them to; I told him that words carry past owners in their seams, and he said yes as if I had just announced that chairs remember thighs. Alba spent the morning in the studio building a model out of cardboard that complained; her hands came home with glue on them like small bandages. Carmen texted a picture of the hospital curtain under stage lights and it did look like it had something to confess. My father worked late because happiness makes him shy and work does not, and Alba’s mother made soup that tasted like a decision.

Friday arrived with the self-importance of a person who believes in calendars. My mother asked to meet again; I said okay because no one has ever died of okay, which is a lie, but one I told myself for sport. We walked by the river that pretends to be serious and isn’t, and she told me about a friend who had become ill and recovered, and I told her about Alba’s hospital and how the windows that face parking lots can still contain trees. She did not ask about Alba in the way that would have forced me to draw a map; she asked like a person who remembers that step-sister is a word you wear until it either fits or tears you. When we came to the bridge that thinks it is an eyebrow, she stopped and looked downstream and said, “I should have stayed,” and for a second I saw her at our kitchen table with the lemon magnet and the kettle pretending to be a locomotive, and I was angry because a sentence can be true and arrive too late to save anyone.

“You didn’t,” I said, and the words were not a slap, but they knew where her face was. She nodded. We turned back toward the station because promises to ourselves are important even when they are about leaving. We said goodbye without arrangements; she touched the sleeve of my coat again and it did not feel like a claim. In the afternoon I put my head down on my desk and let the wood tell me its version of events. The cactus on the sill had produced a bud so small it could have been a trick of the light.

That night the power went out for the whole block with the drama of an opera that had been waiting for its cue.
