The refrigerator sighed and stopped pretending it was necessary; the record player went still; the kettle, bless it, kept its godhood because gas doesn’t bow to electricity. We lit the candles that people who don’t believe in romance keep for blackouts, and the flat rearranged itself into a ship with rooms that glowed like small ports. My father did that thing where men bang the fuse box with a friendly fist; Alba’s mother distributed blankets like medals. Alba and I sat on the floor with the sketchbook open to a page where she had drawn stairs that admitted defeat gracefully. In the dark the pencil made a sound like a moth on a window.

“Tell me something true you haven’t said out loud,” she said, and the request landed like a gentle trauma. The candlelight performed its cruelty on our faces, revealing softnesses we had been hoarding.

“I’m not sure I know the difference between wanting to be held and wanting to be seen,” I said, and the sentence surprised me by being already formed when it left my mouth. She nodded as if this had been on her list of things about me that felt inevitable. The kettle chose that moment to sing, and we laughed in self-defense at the ways that drama chooses its cues.

“Your turn,” I said, because fairness is one of my least fraudulent virtues.

“I think,” she said, and shifted her shoulder against the cabinet, “that I came here to build rooms and found myself trying to build a person I could be in them. León was a place where I was good at stairs. Oviedo is a place where I am practicing doors.”

“And?” I said, because the candle had decided to burn like a witness.

“And I want you,” she said, with that terrible generosity of leaving you to decide what the sentence means, “in my buildings. In the ones that force kindness. On the stairs that are for sitting. In the rooms that only have windows, so we are forced to look.”

I did not kiss her. The power had gone out, but not my good sense or my fear. I put my hand flat on the sketchbook and felt the paper thin my pulse out into the room, and I said, “I am here,” which is a sentence that can hold more than it appears to. She put her hand over mine for the length of a candle’s wobble and then took it away, not because she wanted to, but because we both were still the kind of people who believed in being able to sleep.

The power came back with a shrug and the refrigerator rejoiced in its whirr and the record player blinked its small light and pretended it had never been dead. We put a record on and it crackled back to itself and Monk played something that made the room decide to exhale, and my father came into the kitchen to say that the block had cheered at the sound of the football game returning to its screen next door, and Alba’s mother smiled into her soup like a person who has finally registered her own victory. Later, in bed, I allowed my body to be tired and not just dramatic, and I dreamt that the cactus burst into flowers and that the pigeons delivered invitations in their beaks to a building with no doors at all.

On Sunday I went to Alba’s aunt’s apartment where there were nineteen people in a space meant for ten and everyone had decided to shout love at one another in two dialects. They served fabada that stood up for itself in the bowl; they insisted I eat as if they had sponsored my mouth. Alba’s mother told the story of the registry and made it funnier than it had been because she can make forms into jokes; my father laughed the way men laugh when they have been forgiven and don’t trust it yet. Alba’s cousins asked me whether linguistics can make a person stop lying and I said no, only better at it. We went home with containers full of soup like luggage for the week, and the lemon magnet held up a new drawing of a window that had decided it was a question.

For a few days, the city pretended it had been easy all along. Classes behaved like themselves, which is to say inconsistent. The hospital receded into a story we could tell people when they needed proof that we had done winter properly. Carmen had her opening night and we sat in the eighth row and watched her wrestle with sentences the way you wrestle with a wet sheet, and she won more often than she lost, and afterward in the bar she told us that acting is just the art of being a person when too many people are watching. Mara rolled her eyes and bought her a beer. My mother texted me a picture from the train window of a field that had decided to be blank, and said, I will write, and I believed that the way you believe a liar when you want the night off from caution.

Late in the week, I went to the bookstore on Calle San Francisco alone because the rain had decided to be made of needles and I wanted a shadow to lean into. The man behind the counter looked up as if expecting me to carry a catastrophe and was mildly disappointed that I had only brought dampness. I wandered the aisles and let the books breathe on me. In the corner where poetry pretends to be patient, I found a slim volume about doors in old cities, their measurements and myths, the thresholds where brides tripped and wolves chose not to enter, and there was a chapter on hinges that made me feel like someone had been eavesdropping on my private metaphors. I did not buy it because money is a language I do not speak fluently this month; I stood and read instead until the man behind the counter coughed in a way that suggested I should practice leaving.

When I came out, the woman with the pigeons had taken shelter under the awning and the pigeons milled like guilty confessions at a public hearing. She nodded at me and said, “They follow food and weather, like anyone,” and I nodded back as if she had granted me a doctorate in practical philosophy. At home, Alba was on the floor with the model, convincing a small wall to behave with a strip of tape. She looked up and the look landed on me as if I had walked into a sentence that had been waiting for me to finish it.

“We need more glue,” she said, pragmatic as oxygen. “And a better fire plan.”

“We always need a better fire plan,” I said, and then I sat down cross-legged on the floor and took the tape when she offered it and held the tiny corridor while she pressed it into obedience. The kettle announced time and we let it. The records had started to warp at the edges because we are not careful enough with heat; the Monk still played perfectly, as if certain wrongnesses are built to endure. When the phone rang later, it was not my mother and not a hospital and not any of the disasters I rehearse. It was a number I did not know that turned out to be the program coordinator for a small reading at the university café, asking if I would come and read the iron rain poem because someone had told her I had a mouth that could make buses sound like whales. I said yes because sometimes you say yes to something that is not the thing you want most in order to remember how yes feels.

And on Friday, because weeks do not run out of ways to invent themselves, we were on the balcony in a drizzle that was more opinion than weather, and Alba said, “Do you ever feel like a hinge?” and I said, “Yes,” and she said, “Good. Then it’s not just me,” and the two of us stood there and moved nothing and held everything together for another day.

Chapter 6 began like a door that had been painted shut and was suddenly asked to remember its purpose. The city woke under a glaze that wasn’t rain so much as breath returned to glass, and the chimneys stood like exclamation points nobody had earned. In our flat the kettle tried to startle the morning into good behavior and the record player sat with its lid up as if listening for instructions. My father hummed a tune from a decade that never quite belonged to him and put his jacket on the chair in case he decided to leave, which is how he prepares for any day that might ask him to be different. Alba was already at the table with a pencil behind her ear and the model of the Building of Necessary Closeness half-assembled, its cardboard corridors arguing softly with the tape. She had made a tiny sign for the stair to nowhere that said, in letters you could only read if you were already in love with the idea, practice.

She looked up when I came in with the sleep still folded into my eyes and said, “How do you feel about microphones?” The pencil fell forward from her ear like a decision.

“Like I feel about umbrellas,” I said, reaching for the kettle and finding it too hot to touch. “Useful, deceitful. They fail exactly when the weather is most itself.”

“Good,” she said, and her smile had that slant it has when she knows she’s being kind to my panic by pretending to joke with it. “The café has one that was found in a broom closet and rescued. Carmen says it works like a dog with an opinion.”

“I can project,” I said, more bravely than I felt. “The problem is not air. The problem is the ownership of it.”

“You read like you pour coffee,” she said, and she wasn’t teasing. “As if the river had been waiting to be invited into a cup. I’ll be there. You can glare at me if the words try to leave the stage without permission.”

I thought about the poem I’d said I would read and the one that had been busy building itself behind it, using bits of my day like scaffolding. The iron of the rain had chosen me as a faithful correspondent; the pigeons had become a chorus with a sense of humor; the corridors wanted to be a metaphor and a floor plan simultaneously. I buttered bread with the care of a novice surgeon, because breakfast is sometimes just a rehearsal for public acts. Alba cut an orange into eight precise segments and declared them tickets, and we ate them as if there would be a door somewhere later that would require proof of our citrus.

The university café had taped the poster with my name spelled correctly and the month mislabeled, as if someone had negotiated with time and lost the small print. The window chalk announced happy hour for a coffee that could not remember its own smile. Inside, the chairs were pretending to be attentive and the lampshades hung at a degree that made me feel like I was already on stage. Carmen arrived too early with a scarf that had decided to be a dare and said, “You will be fine, and if not, I will stage a diversion by climbing onto a table and reciting the safety instructions from an airplane,” which, terrifyingly, she would. Mara came with a notebook and a pen and the calm of a person who has volunteered to be my witness whether I fall or fly. My father texted a picture of a teacup from his desk as if to bless the event long-distance, and Alba’s mother promised soup later as if broth were a language we all shared no matter what else we couldn’t say.

An hour before the reading my phone pulsed with a message that landed like a hand laid too gently on my shoulder. I’ll come if I may, my mother wrote, and there was a mercy in the conditional that I could not afford to examine for too long. I typed back a single word that is both door and barrier—okay—and felt it lodge in the architecture of my throat. I did not tell my father because I am good at triage when it concerns information; I told Alba and she touched her eyebrow the way she does when she’s measuring a wall and said, “We will sit where we can see you and the exit,” and I almost laughed from the relief of someone who understands how to design for floods.

The program began with a boy who announced he was “more into prose poetry actually,” which meant he read a paragraph about the sea and a cinnamon roll as if they had broken up with him over the phone. A woman with a voice like rain on tin took the microphone and made it behave, and the room turned the volume of its breathing down to polite. Then the coordinator said my name and my name, when said into a microphone, felt like a word being asked whether it enjoys its own weather. I stood and the chair gave up the idea of me with a squeak that sounded like a hinge. Alba’s eyes were where I needed them: steady, just to the left of the mic, a small lake that had decided to reflect only the necessary light. Carmen folded herself into enthusiasm beside her; Mara uncapped her pen and looked at me the way you look at a person who is about to cross a narrow bridge with their eyes open.

I read the poem about iron and rain and the way buses inhale before they exhale us back into our weather, and people did the thing I had secretly hoped for and had pretended not to hope for: they leaned. The café’s clatter consented to a half-minute of silence exactly when I described the woman who feeds pigeons as if they were a committee, and someone in the back made a sound that might have been an agreement. The microphone hummed once like a reluctant appliance and then decided to be good. I let the next poem arrive with its own feet; it had the corridors of Alba’s building in it and the injunction against passing without touch, and it had a stair that stopped to invite conversation, and it had a door that had been painted shut, asked to remember, reminded gently that remembering is sometimes just not resisting. I said the word please and let it belong to both me and the person who had texted it. I did not look at the back of the room until that word had done its work.

My mother had chosen a place by the window where the glass collected the outside in pieces and tried to assemble a coherent weather. She was smaller than she had been two years ago, or my memory had inflated her to the size of her leaving. She leaned forward the way people do in cafés when they are trying to remember how to belong, and when she saw me see her she did not smile so much as let the possibility of smile hover in the vicinity of her mouth. I kept reading because stopping would have been a betrayal of the air the room had already exchanged with me. I made my voice do the thing Alba had accused it of: being a blanket, being a talking handrail, being the particular kindness of a bridge.

The microphone chose the last line to go on strike and I finished without it, finding out that my ribs can be a drum if I ask them nicely. The applause landed like rain on paper and did not tear it. People came to tell me what my words had reminded them of, which is the ritual we perform to let the poet believe in the usefulness of their particular noise. Alba didn’t come forward right away; she held her position at the edge, as if guarding the door that leads from one version of me to the next. Carmen hugged me with the generosity of a person who considers accolade a communal resource. Mara said, “You did not disgrace any trains,” which, coming from her, is thunderous praise.

My mother did not approach until the wave had receded and I had put the microphone back in its stand as if returning a loaned instrument. She stood beside a table with a bowl of lemons that had no right to be there in a café, just as we had brought them to the registry office as if to annotate bureaucracy. “T,” she said, quietly, and I wondered briefly whether she had practiced the letter aloud in the train window to see if it still fit her mouth.

“Hello,” I said, and when I did not drown, I thought about how sometimes survival is simply a matter of where you put your feet. We walked to a corner that had room for two people to be awkward without causing a structural failure. She said the poems had made her want to phone a city and apologize to it, which is exactly the kind of thing she would say when she wanted me to know she had been listening even if she did not know what to do with the information.

“Thank you for coming,” I said, because I have learned to hand out polite phrases as if they were life vests. “I’m meeting my family for dinner. We can—tomorrow—coffee somewhere that isn’t a kitchen.”

She nodded and didn’t do the thing she might have done, which is to ask to bend that rule. “I’m staying near the station,” she said. “There’s a café that pretends to be Paris. Eleven?”

“Eleven,” I said, and her face moved into gratitude so quickly it startled me into forgiving the word for all its losses. She didn’t touch my arm this time, which made it easier to keep all my bones where they belonged. When she left, she did it like a person leaving a church quietly, borrowing the silence that wasn’t hers and promising to return it.

At dinner my father poured soup as if accuracy were a second language he had recently decided to master. Alba’s mother over-salted and then added a peeled potato the way her own mother had taught her, remedying and remembering in the same motion. Alba sat opposite me and made a circle in her bowl with the back of her spoon as if beginning a sketch in broth. We talked about the reading using only nouns and the jokes that live near nouns; we did not say mother, which felt like both a mercy and a cowardice. After, my father washed each bowl as if returning it to a calmer version of itself and went to his room with the deliberate gait of a man who will wait by a phone until sleep kills the lights.

Alba and I took our tea to the balcony because the air had chosen to be honest about its chill. Below us a cat claimed a stretch of curb with the right born of repetition, and above us the chimney measured time with the absence of smoke. “You did that,” she said, and I pretended not to know whether she meant the reading or the act of surviving my mother’s presence. “You put verbs on things that thought they were nouns, and they didn’t even get offended.”

“I was less afraid when the microphone died,” I said. “Which seems like a metaphor with ambitions.”

“We always liked candles in blackouts,” she said. “Why should this be different? Also, you pronounced se with more tenderness than is strictly necessary. Your professor would be charmed into correcting you.”

“Wait until he hears my ode to the passive,” I said, and she laughed quietly, a sound that has learned the difference between making light and being it. We stood without speaking for a minute that widened like a door that had finally remembered its hinges. She reached up to tuck hair behind her ear and her knuckles brushed my sleeve, and it felt like a bird landing on a branch it has been pretending not to look at. We let the moment sit between us on our balcony that faced almost nothing and we refused to name it because our names had been doing heavy labor all week.

The next morning I went to meet my mother at the café that pretended to be Paris. The tables were mean to elbows and the croissants were ambitious without being arrogant. She wore the same coat as Friday, which meant she had decided not to spend on appearances what she might need for absences. We spoke like people who know how to keep a conversation from turning into a trap. She told me about a book club that had saved her from an apartment that made silence loud; I told her about a list of streets with trees and how the hospital window had hosted a leaf that insisted on a season. When she asked if I was happy, I told her the truth’s cousin: that I had become more precise about what happiness is not.

She asked, as if asking to borrow sugar, if she might see me again before she went back, and I said yes on the condition of public benches and cafés and the city as witness. She accepted the terms and did not pretend they weren’t terms, which made it possible for me to keep breathing on a weekday. We parted with a handshake that both of us permitted to be a little absurd. The woman with the pigeons nodded at me as if to say, yes, today is a day you stood in the weather and did not invent new weather to replace it.

Back home, the cactus had finally decided to be dramatic according to its own schedule. A bud had opened into a tentative white that looked like a small confession, and it did it in daylight to surprise us. Alba crouched to look at it closely, her hair falling forward like a curtain someone had decided not to shut all the way. “They do this once and then never again or once a year and pretend it costs them nothing,” she said, and she did not touch the flower, which made me love her with a ferocity I hid by rearranging lemons.

We took the model to the studio for a review and watched it survive the elevator like a brave patient. The professor with storm-cloud hair came by and flicked a stair with her finger to see if it would admit its uselessness. “You still want to force people to brush past each other,” she said, “in a culture that prefers to pretend the walls are benevolent.”

“I want to design for what we fear,” Alba said, and the professor smiled in that way that meant she had been waiting for that answer and would not punish its predictability. “I added a courtyard for air. I will affix small trees that will fall off if the glue refuses to believe in me.”

“Make the trees convincing enough that the fire inspector breathes differently,” the professor said, and pinned a note onto the board: Don’t apologize to the walls. After the review, Alba and I walked to the theater because Carmen had asked for arms to carry a prop wardrobe that had started to think it was a character. We found her arguing lovingly with a bolt of fabric, her hair a half-blue weather report. “You were good,” she said to me, without overture, which told me someone had been in that café who later told someone who later told her. “You made the room a corridor, and people touched, even if only with their faces.”

“You steal metaphors for breakfast,” Mara said, appearing with a cup that announced a loyalty to bitter coffee. “Also, your curtain needs washing.”

“I like a curtain that looks like it remembers the last body that passed it,” Carmen said, and they resumed their rivalry for the sovereignty of sentences. I let their talk move over me like a stage light and helped carry the wardrobe that had decided it wanted to know what the sun is.

That evening, the university café messaged to ask if I might read again next month, this time with a theme that pretended to be about cities but was actually about being honest when the world is listening and you’d prefer it looked away. I said yes without asking permission of my fear and then told it anyway, and it sulked briefly and then agreed to play along if I promised to over-prepare. At home my father had bought a cheap hinge and oil because the balcony door had been complaining in a voice we had decided was charming until it wasn’t. I watched him unscrew and adjust, and the way the door swung after—smoothly, without announcement—felt like both a loss and a mercy. “Sometimes we need the squeak,” I said, and he nodded as if I had offered him a memory he could put in his jacket pocket.

Late, in the hour where the refrigerator thinks it is the only machine awake, Alba knocked on my door, not a performative tapping but the precise rhythm of permission. She stood with the sketchbook in her hands like a petition and came in when I said yes as if we had been practicing this choreography for months. “I want to rewrite the corridor,” she said, sitting on the floor, her back against my bed. “The narrowness should be generous. That sounds impossible, but so does weather that tastes like iron, and here we are.”

We drew options and rejected them and tried again, and I made a list in the margin for her of all the moments I had felt the city require nearness: the bus stop when the rain had insisted, the registry office with its ferns, the hospital elevator, the aisle between poetry and theory at the bookstore on Calle San Francisco. She added her own: the stage wings, the distance between kettle and cup, the space where my name had been signed in her book and the paper hadn’t protested. We laughed at the way we were both showoffs when nobody was watching, and we sat long enough that the night turned over and presented its other cheek.

“I should tell you something,” I said, because Mara’s voice lived in my brain as a benevolent bossy ghost. “It is not information so much as an orientation. When I am near you, I become precise in a way that makes the rest of my life both easier and impossible.”

“I know,” she said, without triumph and without sorrow, and a small piece of me unclenched, the way hands do when they realize they will not be asked to carry their own weight forever. “I am drawing stairs for us that are mostly for sitting. We can forgive whatever we cannot climb yet.”

We did not kiss, which is not a vow of purity so much as an agreement with time. We sat there with graphite on our fingers and tea we had forgotten to drink going cold, and at some point our shoulders leaned until they were a single line that would be hard to draw without a ruler. When she left, she placed the sketchbook by my lamp and said, “I am putting this here not because I don’t trust my room but because I like the idea of these drawings sleeping under your breathing.” When she closed the door, it did it without a squeak and I wasn’t sure if that was a triumph or a failure I would learn to forgive.

The week folded itself like a map that remembers all the places your fingers pressed down. My mother, obedient to the rules I had asked for, wrote a message with a picture of a café spoon and a line about trains that apologized twice and meant it once. My father bought lemons as if the fruit could guarantee the right kind of tartness to our days. Alba’s mother learned how to make a stew from her sister’s recipes without calling her for help and celebrated by inviting us all to eat it as if victory were a spice. Carmen’s show extended its run by three nights and she walked around the city like a person who has found a door that finally recognized her as its own and opened on the first knock. Mara took my poem and put it in her notebook as if storing a friend’s spare key.

On Thursday, the hospital called, but it was Nurse Ana inviting us to a volunteer recital that Nano had conned the ward into hosting. “Spectacular,” she said, and you could hear the grin in the word. “Bring your lists. The boy with the former cast wants to see if you’ve learned new vocabulary for mischief.” We went because saying yes to that building now felt like a way of honoring its stubborn intention to be a place where ends and beginnings share a wall. The ward smelled as it always had: oranges, gel, the soft tyranny of clean. The guitar volunteer was there, and a woman who looked like she had answered phones for a decade and then given the job her heart. Carmen recited a monologue from the play that had discovered its legs, and she did the nurse line without irony, and the real nurse who had given the line to fiction stood with her hand over her mouth struggling not to ruin her mascara. The boy drew me as a bus with wings and told me that this was how he imagined being released into a city. Alba stuck the drawing to the wall with medical tape and wrote under it in small letters, permission.

We walked out into a dusk that pretended it had invented itself just for us and turned at the corner where the vending machine now gave bananas that tasted like birth. Alba reached for my hand without ceremony when a motorbike roared too close to the curb, and I took it the way you take a tool you have already learned the weight of. We did not make it into a declaration, and we did not pretend it was nothing. We carried it to the bus stop and released it there because nearness is sometimes a public utility and sometimes a private altar, and the city was listening.

When the rain returned, it did so in a thin script across windows and cheeks. I read again at the café with the microphone that had learned to trust me, and a woman asked afterward whether the pigeons in my poems were metaphors or if I meant actual birds. “Both,” I said, unable not to be myself, and she looked relieved, as if permission to believe two things at once had been withheld from her until now. My mother texted a photograph of a train ticket’s underside for no reason I could parse and wrote, “I’ll be back in a month,” and I did not write back until the next day because politeness is a tool and sometimes a weapon, and I am learning when to put my hands down.

The cactus chose, on a Tuesday at two in the morning, to open every bloom it had. Alba knocked on my door a more urgent rhythm and said, “Now,” and we stood in our socks near the windowsill and watched the flowers declare their foolish and perfect purpose. They smelled like milk and a decision postponed and finally made. We breathed like careful thieves, stealing what we were being given and promising to return it unharmed. “They’ll close by noon,” Alba said, her voice quiet with awe and regret. “It’s all at once, and then they pretend they never did it.”

“We’ll make a list,” I said, because I am not original when faced with miracles. “This, and the hospital courtyard light at four, and the sound of buses when they don’t see you, and the way a hinge feels just before the oil decides to forgive it, and your professor’s smile when you told her you wanted to design for what we fear, and my father’s hands when he’s trying to turn a lemon into evidence.”

“We will make a building,” she said, “with a room that insists on blooming at unreasonable hours.” We stood there until the flowers finished their sentence. When we finally slept, it was with the certainty that morning would pretend nothing had happened and that we would be brave enough to contradict it, gently.

In the afternoon, we hung the boy’s drawing of the winged bus on our kitchen wall, below the lemon magnet, where it could learn the geography of our domestic weather. Alba added, in graphite, a tiny hinge in the corner of the page, not to be cute, but as a reminder of the quiet miracle that allows doorways to be both threshold and place to lean. I oiled the balcony’s new hinge once because I am greedy for smoothness and then regretted it and learned to listen harder for the soft announcement of approach. The kettle, indifferent to metaphor, announced only itself and demanded we come make tea. We did, and the record player obliged the day with an old crackle and a piano that knows how to make a room exhale, and our family was a choreography that had learned more steps than it intended and performed them without falling.

If you ask me when the part of the story you’re waiting for arrives, I can only tell you that we were already in it, that arrivals are sometimes just the moment you realize you haven’t been waiting at all, you’ve been walking. The city, in its iron and lemon wisdom, gave us what it gives everyone: weather and stairs and the option to hold onto the railing. We took it. We looked out, and in, and then we made another list, and then we put the list in the drawer with the spoons, because we believed in needing it again.

Chapter 8 began on a day that believed itself to be ordinary and betrayed that belief by putting a small flag of light on the kitchen table where no window could have reached. The kettle staged its coup as usual; the radio measured traffic with its dry wrist; my father buttered toast with the concentration of a man who wants to keep disaster from hearing him eat. Alba had fallen asleep at the table over the model and woke with a cardboard triangle stuck to her cheek like a temporary tattoo. She peeled it off with dignity and set it on the stair to nowhere labeled practice, as if the model had been waiting overnight for an emblem. I made a list under my breath of rooms that deserve names and never get them—the space between kettle whistle and cup, the three steps between a hospital bed and the window, the balcony where pigeons rehearse judgment—and Alba listened the way a person listens to a weather report for a city she has not visited yet. I could tell from the set of her mouth that her professor had assigned something that required cruelty to be useful; I could tell from the way she tucked hair behind her ear that she was secretly excited to invent a solution nobody had thought to forbid. Carmen had sent a message at dawn that said, The curtain finally confessed. It smells like apology and I forgive it. Mara had sent one that said, You owe me two coffees for surviving last night’s prose-poem boy, and attached a photograph of a croissant with a bite taken out that looked eerily like Oviedo’s skyline. The city, outside our windows, did its exercise: buses expanding their lungs, rain stretching in thin bands between buildings, the woman with the pigeons deploying slices of stale baguette like treaties.

I went to a morning class where the professor discussed clitic doubling as if it were a cousin who had moved in without asking and everyone had decided it was fine, and I learned nothing that would help me in the corridor between my door and Alba’s. On the way out, a flyer flapped against the bulletin board declaring a spring festival I had forgotten the city hosts every year, promising balloons that would look sad by afternoon and music that would not be embarrassed to be performed in daylight. I took one of the tear-off tabs because I am weak in the face of paper strips inviting me to be social, and I texted a picture to Alba with the caption Research into public corridors, and she sent back a pencil emoji and a lemon and a drawing of a staircase that looked like a party hat. My phone pulsed a text from my mother that I did not open for three minutes to see if my blood had learned patience; when I opened it, it said, I found a door in Madrid that reminded me of ours. It was painted shut. I had the urge to knock anyway. I stared at it until the letters looked like a language I had yet to study, then put the phone face down and told myself that images are not obligations. At home, the balcony hinge that my father had oiled moved like a dancer who had decided to be gracious, and for a moment I resented the absence of squeak because it meant I had lost another method for detecting approach.

Alba had a site visit that afternoon to a half-abandoned factory on the edge of the city where rust and geometry had been negotiating for decades without a union. She asked if I wanted to come, not because she needed an extra set of eyes, but because she has learned that I relax in the presence of things that admit their age. The bus there breathed opinions out its windows and dropped us in a neighborhood that specialized in remembering better days without hating the present. The factory had the dignity of a horse that has decided not to run anymore but will still tolerate a hand on its neck. Alba led me through a hole in a fence made polite with a piece of wire so the cut wouldn’t catch on coats; inside, the floor had gathered the dust of five kinds of work and decided not to distinguish. Light entered through broken panes as if embarrassed by the grandeur of its entrance, and weeds rehearsed their insistence in the cracks. Alba set her bag down on a concrete ledge as if claiming a desk and began to draw the negative space between columns. “I love buildings that admit they have been used,” she said, her pencil marking time. “And I love the arrogance of a door that still believes it can open even when somebody painted it shut twenty years ago. It holds its hinge like a secret.” I walked the perimeter counting windows that had lost a pane and kept their shape anyway and thought about how language announces itself even in silence: the way you feel the difference between empty and vacant, the way abandonment smells like a particular decade of floor cleaner. When I came back to her side, she had drawn a corridor that would run through the center of the factory like a spine, wide enough to let mothers with strollers and teenagers who needed to learn how to walk past one another without turning themselves to iron.

We took our research to the river because water is the bachelor apartment of our better ideas, and I sat on the low wall staring at the surface as if hoping for subtitles. Alba flipped the sketchbook closed after a minute, either to keep her lines from escaping or to spare them my weather. “I’m thinking of going to León this weekend,” she said, without a flourish, as if placing a mug on a table to test if the surface wobbled. “There’s a library there with windows that remind you that glass is a form of patience, and my mother wants to return a casserole dish to an aunt who thinks food is a method of attack. Do you want to come and pretend to be objective about my old streets?” The question put its hands in my pockets and waited for my coins. I wanted to say yes the way a person wants to sit on stairs that never end. I wanted to say no because going into her before felt like daring the present to identify itself. I said, “If the bus is cheap, and if Oviedo promises not to be jealous.” She smiled that way she does when I build a cage for a bird and then leave the door open. “It will rain there too,” she said. “The iron tastes different. You can take notes.” We sat until the river decided to change season without telling anyone, and then we walked home through streets that had perfected the smell of damp cardboard and soup.

At the flat, a bouquet of parsley had once again pretended to be flowers on the counter, and my father left us a note propped against the kettle that said Dinner at seven and a half, please remind me to breathe and also to call the plumber about the sink that likes to be a lake. Alba’s mother bustled in with a bag of oranges and a recipe she had written on the back of a bill because paper is democratic that way. The four of us performed the choreography that has become our religion: slicing, stirring, discussing the day as if it were a country we could hold between thumb and forefinger and examine for counterfeit. When we sat, my father said grace in the language of spoon placement and my name, and Alba’s mother told us a story about her sister and a roast chicken that had nearly proposed marriage, and I watched Alba draw a door in her soup with her spoon and resist walking through. After, while the dishes considered their mortality in the sink, my phone hummed with my mother’s persistence. This time the message was not a story but an explicit question: May I bring you something from Madrid that you cannot get there? Please say yes. I took the phone to the balcony and considered composing a list that would punish and forgive simultaneously—things like patience, absence that doesn’t announce itself, a night that ends when it should—but lists are my tools, not my weapons, and I refused to blunt them against our old stone. I wrote back, Bring me a notebook with strong paper. And a pen that doesn’t run. The ones that can take ink like a sky takes weather. She sent a heart that looked embarrassed to be so pink and wrote, I can do that.

The spring festival arrived like someone’s cousin who always suggests karaoke and then sings better than anyone expected. The square bloomed with stalls selling objects that should not have been beautiful and were: woven baskets the color of rainwater, cheap bracelets that would make the wrists of teenagers into declarations, a knife sharpener who whistled like a kettle whenever he found the edge. The woman with the pigeons had retired to a bench and allowed children to take her place; they deployed bread with a strategy that made the birds reconsider their politics. Alba and I wandered, making an architectural survey of temporary structures, and I argued for the genius of a tent that had no right angle to its name. Carmen found us with a pretzel the size of her head and a grin the size of the day and declared, “You have not lived until you have seen a mayor dance to a brass band without shame,” and dragged us toward the stage where the city fathers and mothers performed their particular version of belonging. Mara joined with a paper cone of chestnuts that burned our fingers in a way that felt like a moral. We watched a clown convince a group of solemn eight-year-olds that their seriousness was a party hat in disguise, and we listened to a soap seller pitch his lathers with the patter of a man versed in repentance, and we let the afternoon be as long as it wanted to be.

It was almost virtuous, the amount of normalcy we performed, until Alba’s mother noticed a woman across the square whose coat I had come to know too well at a distance. My mother stood near the lemonade stall, considering a jar of something that had been called honey by a person willing to commit to that lie, and she did not see us because her eyes were busy auditioning sweetness. My father’s back went straight, the way it does when he is about to get through something by pretending nobody is looking. Alba’s mother squeezed his forearm once and then put her hand around her cup of coffee as if it had asked to be held through a storm. “Do you want to leave?” Alba asked, softly, offering me the corridor out, offering to become the door. I looked at my mother’s profile which is a sketch my muscles know how to flinch at, and I felt the precise weight of the pen she had promised, and I said, “No. We can let the square be big. It is allowed to contain her and us without collapsing.” We stood our ground without pretending to be rooted, and my mother eventually looked up, saw us, and did not approach, which felt like a discipline I had not credited her with. She lifted the jar at me as if to ask, Do you believe in honey in this weather, and I lifted my paper cone of chestnuts and shrugged, and the conversation ended there without anyone losing skin.

We went to León on Saturday under a sky that could not be bothered to choose a mood. The bus climbed past hills that had decided green was not a color but a manifesto, and Alba pointed out the derelict silos with more affection than derelict structures are used to. León tasted like an old coin put under the tongue, copper and promise, and the streets remembered her in the way that streets do when a body has worn them properly. She took my hand without speeches when a crowd pressed us and let it go when the plaza widened, and in that space between I discovered an entirely new way to measure distance. We went to the library she loves and sat under windows that made the sky into geometric proofs; the room was full of that particular hush in which people dare silence to tell on them. Alba opened a book of buildings and showed me a staircase someone had made to be climbed only by the patient or the obsessive, and I took out the notebook my mother had given me at the station that morning, black cover, paper that promised to accept mistakes gracefully, and I wrote three sentences about the shape of a pause.

We ate in a cafe with chairs that insulted knees by being too low, and Alba drew a plan on a napkin for a courtyard with weather admitted on a schedule, and I drew next to it a list of words that change shape under pressure—yet, perhaps, still—and between us we made a place where strangers would be forced to confess their smallness and walk away taller. In the afternoon we visited her aunt with the casserole dish; the aunt was a person for whom hospitality was a sport and she had been training since the nineties. She looked me up and down with the efficiency of a customs agent and decided I could pass; she crushed almonds into a paste and insisted I learn the correct wrist for stirring, which apparently I have. She asked questions that treated us as if we were an old couple who had mislaid our wedding rings during a flood; we answered politely and inaccurately. On the bus back, Alba fell asleep with her head against the window, and I watched her reflection superimpose on farms and gas stations and late trains, and I thought about how the word step had failed to contain us from the start and how verbs are better than nouns for the weather we were in.

Back in Oviedo, the week tried to revert to its template and failed because the template had been redrawn. I read again at the café with the microphone that now leaned toward me like a dog amenable to instruction. My mother came and sat in the back and did not wave, and afterward she put a pen in my hand that was the kind of blue that lends itself to letters you regret and said, “Paper is the only thing that forgives me,” and I did not confess that I have preferred walls. My father and Alba’s mother came on Thursday, the night I read the poem with the stair that refuses to go anywhere without telling you why, and their applause together made a new sound, a kind of domestic weather being recorded for the first time. Carmen brought three actors who heckled me lovingly with fingers snapped in rhythm and then bought me a beer with money they would regret spending on me in two days. Mara rolled her eyes when a boy recited a poem in which he was a wolf and the city was a forest that did not understand him, and then she kissed my cheek and said, “You are managing not to drown in a cup. I am proud of you,” which is the kind of sentence that lasts for weeks.

The hinge you are waiting for squeaked in private first. It was late; rain had convinced itself it was necessary; the kettle had all but lost its voice from overuse. Alba and I sat at the kitchen table after the parents had gone to bed, the sketchbook between us like a treaty that also functioned as a mirror. She had put the Building of Necessary Closeness aside for the evening and was drawing faces without permission from their owners: my father thinking about nothing out loud for once, Carmen rehearsing with a whistle in her teeth, Mara preparing to destroy a boy’s argument at fifty paces. She drew me last, a mercy and a cruelty, and when she finished a line and turned the book so it faced me, I felt the small click in my chest like a lock receiving the proper key. She had drawn my mouth as if it was carrying a confession and my collarbone as if it remembered a hand. Beneath, in small tidy letters, she had written, “T gathers light like a misplacing and then returns it exact.”

I looked up, prepared to make a joke about possession and optics, and found her already looking. I have learned the weight of many looks; this one was calm enough to convince a cat to admit guilt. It did not demand; it did not request; it acknowledged. “I am tired,” she said, and smiled the way you smile when tired is a pronoun. “But not of you.” She reached across the table and put her fingers lightly on my wrist, an angle that gave her plausible deniability if a parent appeared and also made my pulse behave like a small ridiculous horse. We sat that way long enough for the kettle to complain and for the rain to forget why it was here. Then she stood, and so did I, and the distance between standing and not standing turned out to be exactly the length of a hinge.

There is a version of this moment that involves throwing propriety into the sink and explaining ourselves to the wall afterward. We did not take that version. We walked to the balcony in the placebo of a lull and paused under the lamp that makes our skin the color of old photographs. The street below performed its late shift without checking our calendars. Alba turned to me with the caution of a person approaching a dog she knows and loves but does not want to startle. “If we,” she said, and then laughed once at the ridiculousness of beginning with if we when she could have picked any other words, “if we call this a question, will it be easier to answer?” The flower of the cactus across the way had finished its performance days ago and was now a closed fist; we both looked at it as if it might translate.

“I am more patient with questions than answers,” I said, because accuracy is the only gift I trust myself to bring to any altar. I stepped closer by the width of a lemon peel. She stepped closer by the thickness of her pencil shavings collected in a jar. The first touch was not a declaration or a theft; it was an edit. I kissed the corner of her mouth, a place that is overlooked in bad films and beloved in good lives, and she did not startle or sigh or perform anything; she moved toward me the fraction necessary to make the geometry true. It was not a long kiss; it was not a brief kiss; it was exactly the length of a corridor designed by somebody who understands that passing is the same as arriving if you intend well enough. We stood with our foreheads touching afterward like two children who have learned that earthquakes cannot be prevented by posture and decide to try anyway. Then we went back to the table and drank tea that had cooled into a different bargain, and we drew, deliberately, two doors on the same page. On one we wrote later. On the other we wrote now. We agreed to open both, but not at once, because we are not in the business of setting our own house on fire and then praising ourselves for the warmth.

Of course someone knocked, because the universe belongs to playwrights. It was the rhythm of error: three taps too quick, then a hesitation that sounded like the back of a hand wiping sweat from a forehead. Alba slid the sketchbook under a folded newspaper with the fluidity that suggests both guilt and rehearsal. I went to the door and listened the way you listen to pipes; outside, a woman cleared her throat. My mother had decided to test the rules at nine at night, which in my personal system counts as a war crime. “T,” she said, soft enough that a less treacherous door would not have heard. “I’m sorry. The hotel—there was—never mind. I shouldn’t have come.” Alba stood behind me in the kitchen doorway, body like a comma, indicating continuation. I could feel my father’s door across the hall become aware of itself; I could picture his mouth shaping No before Yes and then deciding to say nothing.

I opened the door because the hinge had been oiled and because my cowardice has always been polite. My mother stood there with her coat open and her scarf done up like a complicated apology, hair that had forgotten to care. She held no bags, which made her look less like a danger and more like a sentence that had removed its punctuation. “I know,” she said, preempting me like a person used to arguing against the weather. “No kitchens. I am a kitchen fire. I should leave.” I stepped back enough that she would not be wet by our stairwell rain and not enough to invite her into our low lamp and our kettle’s jurisdiction. Alba moved neither forward nor backward; she acknowledged my mother with a nod that said, I know you are a noun in our grammar and I will not decline you out loud.

“You can stand there,” I said, which sounds like cruelty and is perhaps the most precise kindness I had offered her. “You can tell me what is wrong and I will tell you if I can help without breaking anything we have spent a year repairing.” She breathed, which sometimes counts as a yes. The problem was small and humiliating: her bank card had sulked; the hotel wanted collateral; the friend who would have given her a couch had turned out to be and not to be a friend. I could have summoned a lecture on planning and on weather forecasts; I did not. I handed her the money from the jar we keep for emergencies of a more domestic variety—plumber, light bulbs, lemons—and said, “This is not generosity. This is a system we are participating in. You will return it the way rain returns vapor to the air after having its fun.” She did not cry, for which I would have loved her if loving her were a thing I felt I could do safely; she looked at Alba and said, “Thank you,” without naming her relation, which made me love Alba on the spot with a kind of accuracy that bordered on violence.

When my mother left, the stairwell ate the sound of her steps responsibly. I closed the door. I put my forehead against it like someone eavesdropping on wood. Alba did not come to touch me; she dried a cup that had not been washed yet and placed it in the cupboard without looking. “You did not break anything,” she said into the small domestic noise of porcelain and shelf. “If anything, you repaired something, neatly.” I turned and leaned on the door, too long for it to qualify as a joke. We did not celebrate ourselves. We washed the few dishes that had not asked to be washed and we went to our rooms and we leaned against our own doors for a minute because sometimes you need to share a wall with yourself.

The city delivered the next morning as if nothing had been asked of it in the night. The woman with the pigeons scolded a child for giving too much at once; the buses bargained with lights; the sky pretended to be kind until noon. I met my mother in a café near the station with a chair that had an opinion about my spine, and she handed me an envelope with the money and a receipt from the hotel as if to prove she had not invented the emergency. We drank coffee that had survived a war in its machine, and she told me about her day as if it were a book someone else had left on a table. “I am learning,” she said, “that apology is a skill and not a mood.” I told her about a pen that ran and paper that accepted it and a factory that wants to be a corridor, and we performed the theatrical politeness that keeps certain buildings standing.

The day ended with an event too small to dignify in some narratives and too significant to ignore here: the model of the Building of Necessary Closeness fell off the table. It was nobody’s fault, which, like apology, is an art. One minute the model had been obeying gravity with grace; the next it committed to flight and failed. The narrow corridor split along the seam where we had forced it to be generous. The stair to nowhere detached and lay splayed like a sentence that had forgotten its verb. Alba sat on the floor next to the wreckage and did not touch it because she had learned in hospital rooms that you let broken things declare their injuries before you try to set them. I sat with her and waited for cardboard to admit what it was ready to do. My father crouched with his large careful hands and said, “Tape and time,” as if ordering at a bar. Alba’s mother fetched the good glue from the high shelf where the pharmacy lives and placed it in Alba’s palm with a ceremony that made me feel the weight of small bottles.

We repaired it, which is poetry’s ugly cousin, and we did it with a concentration that canceled the city’s performance outside our windows. The corridor, rejoined, accepted its seam as part of its line; the stair, reaffixed, declared its uselessness with renewed pride. Alba looked at me with glue on her fingers like the evidence of a long letter, and I thought, not for the first time, that the days are not enemies when they hand you this much material. We placed the model back on the table as if returning a body to a bed after making it lighter with names, and the four of us stood around it with the solemnity reserved for the least dramatic sacraments. After, Alba and I took the lemon magnet and moved the boy’s drawing of the bus with wings to make room for a note written in her precise hand: Repair is a form of design. We looked at it, and then we let the kettle boss us back into motion, and the record player consented to be asked and responded with a crackle that sounded like rain remembering how to speak.

Later that night, when the flat had placed its sleeps in the correct rooms, I went to Alba’s door and knocked that permission rhythm we have taught one another. She said, “Yes,” and I entered, which is the most underrated achievement any person can hope for. The sketchbook lay open to the page with later and now; we had drawn the doors and not opened either. I took my pen, the blue my mother had given me as if to atone for every black she had used to write her leaving, and I wrote under later: patience is not postponement; under now I wrote: permission is not ruin. Alba read the annotations as if they were building codes; she looked up and smiled from the muscles in her cheeks all the way to the ones you can’t see and said, “We can work with that.” We turned off the light not because we are chaste or dramatic but because night deserved at least one unobserved generosity, and we sat in the almost-dark with the window letting in the iron of Oviedo and the soft announcements of buses doing their job, and we leaned shoulder to shoulder like a pair of hinges agreeing not to squeak, not tonight.

Chapter 10 began like a door that didn’t realize it had been left ajar and had the humility to swing itself back without making a speech. The morning put a small coin of sunlight on the floor by the window, a brightness that confused the cat on the balcony below into thinking it had been granted a promotion. The kettle tried to stage its usual coup and failed in a new way; the whistle rose and then flattened into an embarrassed wheeze, like a singer who has woken up in the wrong octave. My father thumped the counter with the heel of his hand as if reminding oak where it comes from would help metal remember its purpose; Alba tilted her head toward the sound, that surgeon’s listening she has, and said, without drama, “It’s the gasket.” I do not know when I learned the word gasket; perhaps it entered the house through the same door as lemon peels and patience. I put my ear near the spout like a person trying to overhear a confession and heard not a failure but a tiredness. “Tape and time,” my father said again, this time to an appliance, and I thought of the note on the model: Repair is a form of design. Outside, the city rubbed its iron into the day until we tasted it with our toast; the woman with the pigeons wagged a finger at a seagull that had wandered into the regime; the buses rehearsed their enunciation and almost got it right.

The university sent me an email with a subject line that inflated itself like a frog: Regional Literary Evening, Confirmed Speakers, Logistics. The body was more polite and less confident; a coordinator asked if I might read two poems and a prose piece because “your work seems to understand that nouns have hearts.” I snorted into the cheap yogurt and then wrote back yes, because I am learning that saying yes out loud to the kinds of invitations I used to laminate in my head is a way to become a person other than my worst rehearsal. Alba’s professor, not to be outdone by any frog, had posted the schedule for the end-of-term review and her name appeared in a column under the bold seriousness of External Jury, which meant real architects with opinions fashioned into sharp accessories would stand in front of her cardboard and graphite and tell her who she had been pretending to be. She read the schedule and set it down and slid her pencil under the spine of her sketchbook as if she were tucking a blade into a boot. “Good,” she said, and the word had so much architecture in it that the chairs straightened their backs.

My mother sent the notebook she’d promised, and I hated it a little for being beautiful. It arrived in an envelope that had survived the mail as if the mail had been generous, which is not its reputation. The cover was black and honest; the paper inside had that slight resilience under your finger that says, I will forgive at least two drafts, maybe three. Tucked into the first page was a letter written with the ink that had always been her weakness, a blue that made my mouth think of winter beads on wire when I was small and she used to fix necklaces at the kitchen table as if mending could be a living. I did not read it at the table; I put it under the lemon magnet as if giving it the same jurisdiction as recipes and a child’s drawing of a bus with wings would prove that it could not carry fire. I read it later on the balcony with my shoulder pressed against the cold railing like a person asking a train to please arrive. She wrote sentences like dressing rooms: some mirrors, some hooks to hang anger on, some light that was too forgiving and then suddenly mean. She wrote that apology is a room she keeps sweeping and never finds the corners of; she wrote about Madrid’s doors in summer, how they swell and stick and have to be persuaded without humiliation; she wrote she’d stood outside a painted-shut door with her hand raised and had not knocked for the first time in her life, a personal applause she didn’t trust; she wrote that she had been wrong about the shape of hunger and perhaps about the shape of love. She did not ask me anything, which is a trick I recognized from both good letters and superior manipulation; she happened near me on paper and waited to see if I would follow. I folded the pages back into the notebook and carried it to my desk and set it next to Alba’s sketchbook and the nearness of the two felt like a joke I did not know how to tell.

Carmen dragged us to a post-rehearsal after-something on a Tuesday in a bar two streets from the theater, a place where the lamps pretend to be old and the bottles have learned to present their labels as if they were diplomas. She wore a sweater with a rip at the hem that had transformed into identity, and she had a new way of saying citizen that included the bartender, which is a coup most actors don’t manage. Mara sat with her feet tucked on her chair as if chairs were suggestions and not rules, and they bickered in a way that promised either violence or a collaboration; I am a romantic when it comes to the idea of people who spar with verbs and come away with fewer wounds than better jokes. The power didn’t go out and there were no dragons in the ceiling, so we were forced to admit we like ordinary nights when nobody performs calamity. Alba watched Carmen explain how a line that had refused to be said for a week finally lay down and let itself be rehearsed, and she smiled with her mouth and her fingers, both, because good sentences and good stairs give her the same satisfaction: they bear weight without asking to be admired every second. I sat there trying to remember what it is I know how to do other than hold the ends of someone else’s courage while they tie a knot.

The kettle took its grievance to a higher register the next morning. The gasket, which had been a theory, announced itself as a fact; steam insisted on unprofessional exits. My father took the thing apart on our kitchen table with a concentration he reserves for the moons of Jupiter and receipts, and the kettle, stripped of its lemon anonymity, looked indecent, a naked metal body that had trusted us too much. “We’ll get a new one on Sunday at El Rastro,” Alba’s mother said, using “we” like a truce flag. “If we find the right dent.” Alba, stubborn in a way that sometimes makes me think of saints who refuse to give up roads they loved, said, “We can fix it,” and went to find the brown paper tape and a piece of soft rubber she had kept from some other emergency. We sat as if at the surgery of a brass patient; she patched with that careful hand she uses when disappointment is watching. The whistle returned a portion of itself, just enough to be recognized, and we applauded the way you do when a child bows after a school recital and you are applauding not for music but for courage. “Repair is a form of design,” I said, pointing at the note we’d taped by the model, and my father kissed the gasket with a ridiculous solemnity he would deny in court.

Sundays at the flea market are not Madrid’s Rastro, but Oviedo’s version has learned how to pretend. The stalls spread their pride down a side street that can carry the smell of frying oil and old jeans and optimism without flinching. We went as a unit because that is how we shop when we are pretending not to: Carmen joined as if she had always been invited and began trying on hats nobody asked her to pay for; Mara came because flea markets are where she practices saying no and yes in equal measure; my father held his hands behind his back as if to signal to the years that he would not touch them; Alba and I hunted kettles in the way you hunt deer in films, with coats and code. We found three that qualified for our interest: a blue that was too proud, a stainless one that looked like the future had failed to arrive, and a lemon-yellow twin to ours with a dent in exactly the wrong place, which is to say precisely where memory lives. The vendor, a man with a face built out of old tools and triumphs, saw the way Alba’s eyes did not leave that dent and said, “It works, but you have to speak soft to it.” Alba turned the kettle in her hands like a person evaluating a conch; she looked at me; I looked at my father; he looked at the sky, which had the decency to ignore him. We bought it not to replace but to understand. “We will cannibalize,” Alba said on the walk home, and I loved her with my list-maker’s heart for saying out loud the plan we were not yet ready to sentimentalize: the old giving its small good pieces to the old, so both can continue their impossible work.

The week advanced with the stubborn gait of a person recovering from a knee injury. I rehearsed aloud, sometimes to the lemon magnet, sometimes to the new-not-new kettle, and sometimes to the empty hallway where the sound of my own voice forces me to file my verbs without complaint. The Regional Literary Evening has the kind of name that makes a certain type of poetry curl into itself, but the people in it were the good kind: teachers with permanent markers on their fingers, students with patience in their shirts, an old woman with hair installed like royalty who would tell me afterward that my pigeons reminded her of mass. Alba printed pin-up boards and built a small backup model in case the jury decided to call her bluff on stairs that pretended to do nothing; she wore her pencil behind her ear as if she had been born with it camouflaged in hair. We took turns standing in the kitchen reading and pinning and not fainting. Carmen brought us energy in the form of stolen theater snacks that taste like cardboard and survival; Mara brought us doubt that she had sanded into support.

My mother wrote nothing for three days and then a message that didn’t know whether it was an apology or a weather report. She said she had stood on a Madrid sidewalk and listened to a street musician insist that Thelonious Monk is a city and had resisted the urge to correct him. She said she had found an old photograph of me with my hair in a fight with itself and a lemon in each hand and had had the indecency to cry. She did not ask when she could come again. I replied with a sentence that had been trying to be born for a month: I need you to keep to the rules because I have used up my spare parts on other repairs. She sent back the word understood three times, as if she hoped repetition could be a hinge.

The evening of readings unfolded like a well-behaved train: it arrived, it made its stops, it apologized for delays it hadn’t committed. The room had more people than chairs wanted to accommodate and some of them leaned against the walls in ways that would make a fire inspector sweat with joy. The organizers had hung prints of the city at dusk as if we needed proof of what we were doing; a table at the back held those small bottles of water that make adults feel like children playing conference. I read the bus poem because it now expects to be read when there are microphones and bread; I read the corridor piece because I wanted to say out loud that passing is a kind of architecture, not just courtesy; I read a new paragraph about repair and how tape is a confession and glue an oath. My father sat next to Alba’s mother on the left side as if left side were a meaningful location; they held hands when they forgot to be cautious. Alba sat on the right next to Carmen and Mara and their combined attention behaved like a rope bridge: it swayed, but I trusted it. Halfway through the second piece I saw my mother at the very back, half in the hall, a student’s chair holding her as if chairs should not have been expected to carry that much history. I did not change a word; I did not remove a metaphor I had written with her in mind; I did not add a line to make her life easier or my argument stronger. When it ended, the clapping was the good kind, the clapping that holds no pity in its palms. Alba came to me first, because she knows how to be both now and later; she put her hand briefly on my shoulder, a public gesture that means more to me than any private thunder; Carmen kissed the air near both my cheeks as if blessing me with theatrical unction; Mara squeezed my fingers until my nails were proof that I am alive. My mother approached not like a penitent or a thief but like a citizen of weather; she said “thank you” and nothing else, and I let that be our entire language for a day.

The review was two mornings later in a room that had been painted white so often it had begun to look like a palace that had read an article about restraint. The external jury entered with scarves and opinions; their shoes whispered they had been in buildings we could not afford to visit. Students pinned up their boards with hands that shook in languages I didn’t know the names of; someone dropped a model and four men looked away in polite horror, which is the kindest thing grownups can do when a thing breaks in public. Alba took her place in front of the Building of Necessary Closeness and stood with the posture she keeps for storms: not aggressive, not retreating, simply present. She introduced the stair to nowhere as practice and the corridor as policy; she talked about fire with such respect that one of the men glanced involuntarily toward the exits. They asked her about heat and air and disability and a culture that can barely stand to brush a sleeve against a stranger; she answered in a way that made one of the women look down to cover her smile and then up again to perform rigor. I watched the professor with storm-cloud hair restrain herself from being proud; she succeeded only in the sense that lightning succeeds in being quiet. When Alba finished, there was a kind of silence that feels like a hand extended for a handshake, and then the woman with the serious shoes said, “Your wrongness is useful,” and pinned a note in yellow that read: Keep the nearness; design the mercy with more cruelty. Alba nodded and later, much later, when we were home and the kettle was finally willing to be itself again, she laughed about the paradox of being told to be more cruel in order to reach kindness.

We took the repaired model to an exhibition in a municipal hall that smelled like pension papers and ceremonies. On the walk there it rained sideways with the relish of a master remembering its trick; we wrapped the cardboard in a plastic sheet that had been a painter’s drop cloth when my father tried to teach a wall to behave. At the hall, the corridor to the display room adapted itself into a test of vows: it narrowed twice, inconveniently, and the second time Mara laughed and said, “Your building has manifested.” We turned the model sideways and then diagonally and then stood still until a man with a dolly offered his vehicle like a knight in an elevator. We thanked him and practiced gratitude as a choreography while we cleared a corner of a table and wrestled our cardboard into the slice of space that had been allotted to us by a person who loves metrics. We hung the note Repair is a form of design at the top left, not as doctrine this time, but the way religious people hang a saint beloved for her stubbornness. In the little storeroom beside the hall, where a mop leaned like a person who had seen it all and chosen to remain civil, Alba put her forehead briefly against my shoulder and let out the breath I had heard her collect all morning. I did not take advantage of any of the versions of us that room might have allowed; I stood and leaned back just enough to make it clear I was not giving her to gravity. We listened to the life of the hall—the coughs out front, the municipal clatter, the plastic tarp sighing itself into place—and we laughed because exhibitions are just public storage with better lighting.

That night the rain remembered itself as theater and threw itself at our windows with the same ambition as an actor who has been given one line and decides it is monologue. The new gasket, the old kettle, the replacement kettle, the apartment’s wires, the window’s seal—all held. The ceiling, however, decided to express an opinion above the narrow corridor between our rooms. It began as a single dark petal and then gathered a bouquet; the first drip was the size of a rude remark; the second established a rhythm. We set bowls down like applause. The sound—the high plink of ceramic, the lower thud when the water forgot itself and overshot—became a music that threatened to be a metaphor and therefore had to be interrupted occasionally by laughter. My father called the emergency number for men who believe in ladders and one arrived with the resigned cheer of people who have saved kitchens from worse. He poked the ceiling with the kind of authority that makes even plaster tell the truth; he declared it a roof line sulk; he promised nothing and brought a tarpaulin joy into our house. The hinge squeaked again when he left, and I kept the squeak like a whistle around my neck because not all smoothness is mercy; sometimes you want to be warned when a door decides to love you enough to open.

We decided to be brave in small, repeatable ways. We kissed again, in a kitchen after midnight where the bowls still gathered what the roof could not hold, and we did not leave evidence on the counter except two cups turned upside down to dry in the way my grandmother taught me. We told no one the thing we were telling ourselves, not yet; we agreed with a degree of cruelty that made mercy possible that we would not sacrifice our house to a meaning it could not withstand. We walked in the city not as a demonstration but as practice; our shoulders found a distance that is evident only to the bodies involved; occasionally our hands experimented with gravity and passed, briefly, in a space where passing is a kind of ownership. Carmen noticed once and did not write a play about it; Mara noticed twice and put the knowledge in the place she keeps for people who are not yet ready to congratulate themselves.

Lists returned because I am more myself with them than without. I made a list of things that belong to the wrong rooms: my mother’s letter on the balcony, the lemon magnet in my father’s pocket because he likes to worry it like a coin, the way Alba’s model pieces appear on the bathroom sink like fish that jumped. I made a list of sounds for the hospital ward because Nurse Ana left a voice message that was just the word spectacular and I felt called to respond: the muffled applause of socks on linoleum, Nano’s dragon-free hum near the tape, the guitar’s careless mercy, the click of gel bottles, and the way someone says hello from behind a curtain because privacy has decided to be a joke for five minutes. I made a list of words we must not use yet: girlfriend, betrayal, forever, accident; and a corresponding list of words we could rehabilitate: practice, hinge, corridor, permission.

My mother asked for a time and I gave her one; we sat on a bench where the city lets teenagers try out boredom without lasting harm, and she asked about the reading not so she could say she was there but so she could say I was; she says my name now as if I had some claim to it she is willing to recognize. She did not ask about Alba; she asked about linguistics with that glass in her voice that used to be charm; I told her about the passive habitual and she laughed and said, “Finally a mood I understand,” and it is possible to love a joke without loving the person who made it. When we parted, she touched the notebook as if not sure whether to ask it for custody. I told her she could send sentences into it if they didn’t ask to be answered; she sent three that night that were just descriptions of rain in Madrid and none of them used iron and I decided that was fair.

The city staged a minor riot of spring; the trees on Avenida de Galicia did that thing where they trick you into thinking leaves are a decision you can make every morning; the woman with the pigeons let a toddler hand her a piece of bread to distribute as if training him for a powerful office; the buses, benevolent and tired, carried us away from and toward all the places that make a week hold together. Alba’s model stood at its municipal post as if it had always belonged there, and sometimes when we walked by she would straighten a corner like a mother smoothing a cowlick on a child, and I would pretend not to notice in case my noticing made her stop.

On a Thursday that had grown exhausted from being responsible, Carmen and Mara turned up at our door with a deck of cards and a bag of potatoes, because nothing says you are planning a harmless evening like starchy vegetables and chance. We cooked the potatoes into a thing that argued about the right word for itself and played a game where losing meant you had to confess a small truth that would not break the room. Carmen admitted she steals chalk from rehearsal rooms and feels no remorse because chalk needs more stage time; Mara said she pretends not to know the end of plays she has memorized so she can be newly angry at old men every week; my father said he thinks the lemon magnet is luck and kisses it when he believes we do not see; Alba said she designed the first sketch of the corridor because she wanted to make us all brush by the necessary and now she doesn’t know how to stop. I said I have kept every list I wrote in the hospital in a folder with the spine broken and I open it when I need to remember that attention is political; no one asked me what I mean by political, for which I adored them all.

When we went to bed, the night put one of those false lights on the kitchen table again, a coin we couldn’t account for. The hinge announced, gently, every time someone moved through the hallway, back and forth, back and forth, practicing arrivals that refused to call themselves that. The kettle, repaired, elected to sing rather than wheeze, and there is a humility in fixed things that new things will always envy. I lay there and listened to the apartment’s small congress, and I thought about the page in the sketchbook with the two doors labeled later and now and the annotations we had added and the ones we had yet to earn, and I thought about how to write into a life without setting it on fire first. The answer, when it came, was not complicated and not noble: we would go on, and that would be the bravest thing we could manage, until we could not, and then we would design the repair.
